revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-21 18:51:49.000000000', 'message': 'Database reservations methods performance optimization

In reservation_commit():
Was:
*) 1 request to get all (N) reservations,
*) 1 requrest to get all (M) usages,
*) N query to update all reservations
*) M query to update all usages
Now there is only 1 db request to soft delete N reservations.
result: 1 + 1 + N + M -> 1 + 1 + 1 + M

In reservation_rollback():
Same as in reservation_commit()

In quota_destroy_all_by_project():
Was:
*) 1 request to get all (N) Quotas
*) N request to soft delete all Quotas
*) 1 request to get all (M) QuotaUsage
*) M request to soft delete all QuotaUsages
*) 1 request to get all (K) Reservations
*) K request to soft delete Reservations
Now there are only 3 requests.
result: 3 + N + K -> 3

In reservation_expire():
Was:
*) 1 request to get all (N) reservations
*) N request to get each usage for reservation
*) N request to update each usage
*) N request to soft delete each reservations
Now:
*) 1 request to get all (N) reservations with usages
*) N request to save each reservation
*) 1 request to soft delete N reservations
result: 1 + N + N + N -> 2 + N

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: If6ddbe552b8f562cf6e8649eab96a375c4875487

commit_message:
Database reservations methods performance optimization

In reservation_commit():
Was:
*) 1 request to get all (N) reservations,
*) 1 requrest to get all (M) usages,
*) N query to update all reservations
*) M query to update all usages
Now there is only 1 db request to soft delete N reservations.
result: 1 + 1 + N + M -> 1 + 1 + 1 + M
remove usages save loop, because it will be automaticly make sqlalchemy
session in transaction.__exit__() hook.

In reservation_rollback():
Same as in reservation_commit()

In quota_destroy_all_by_project():
Was:
*) 1 request to get all (N) Quotas
*) N request to soft delete all Quotas
*) 1 request to get all (M) QuotaUsage
*) M request to soft delete all QuotaUsages
*) 1 request to get all (K) Reservations
*) K request to soft delete Reservations
Now there are only 3 requests.
result: 3 + N + K -> 3

In reservation_expire():
Was:
*) 1 request to get all (N) reservations
*) N request to get each usage for reservation
*) N request to update each usage
*) N request to soft delete each reservations
Now:
*) 1 request to get all (N) reservations with usages
*) N request to save each reservation
*) 1 request to soft delete N reservations
result: 1 + N + N + N -> 2 + N

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: If6ddbe552b8f562cf6e8649eab96a375c4875487

commit_message:
Using query.soft_delete() method insead of soft deleting by hand

Change all occurences of:
	query.update({
		deleted:True,
		'deleted_at': timeutils.utcnow(),
                'updated_at': literal_column('updated_at')})
to:
	query.soft_delete()

Make instance_type_access_remove() with 2 db requests instead of 3

Make agent_build_destroy() with 1 db request instead of 2

Fix bug in aggregate_delete() added missing transaction
make it with 2 db requests instead of 3

Make aggregate_metadata_delete() with 1 db request instead of 2

Make aggregate_host_delete() with 1 db request instead of 2

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: I23a85c48474126743c5d02f642baf6047358aae8

perhaps it would be better to do it with a helper method than a monkeypatch. I definitely like having one place to define it, but I understand that monkeypatching can lead to confusion in the future.

something like:
  models.soft_delete(query)

seems like it could be almost as readable and avoid future confusion. I'm not sure the best place to put it. models, session, helpers?"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-21 19:27:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

In my opinion:
We are working with sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query instance: 
The main pattern is:
  query.\
     some_filter_or_join().\
     [.some_filter_or_join()
      ....].\
     some_action(); 

I think, that if we make an external method it will break the nice and clear pattern. (And it will look very ugly and unclear)

About confusion: 
Imagine the new nova db developer. 
He needs to delete something -> He goes to some other method that deletes something and sees there query.some_condition_or_joins.soft_delete() => Ok. He understands that he should use this one. 

So it is pretty simple to understand what it does and how to use it.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-12-21 19:51:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Is there a reason we can't simply subclass sqlalchemy's Query class, add this method, then use that subclass in place of sqlalchemy's Query?"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-21 20:19:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Kelvin, 
Thanks for good advice! 

I looked into sqlalchemy source there is such possibility. (I have already tested it and it works) 

If everyone agrees I will make new patch using inheritance instead of  monkey patching.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-12-21 21:44:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-19 22:51:26.000000000', 'message': "Add soft_delete() method in sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query class

soft_delete() method is dynamically added to Query class in get_maker() method
of session module.

The main idea of this method is to get good performance with clean syntax:

Let we have already `query` instance.

Clean syntax example:
If we want to make soft delete for each entry that correspond to query:
we should write:
        query.soft_delete()
instead of:
        query.update({
                deleted:True,
                'deleted_at': timeutils.utcnow(),
                'updated_at': literal_column('updated_at')})

Performance examples:
If we make:
        query.soft_delete()
we will make only one request to soft delete corresponding entries.
But if we make:
        for model_ref in query.all():
                model_ref.delete(session=session)
it will produce >= N + 1 queries.

In almost all situation it is better to use query.soft_delete() than
model.delete() method, because in second approach we should make
2 request (get model_ref and then soft delete it).

In future patch model.delete() will be at least renamed to model.soft_delete().
Probably it should be removed at all, to avoid situation in code with N+1
requests for soft deletion.

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: I6059982b83648133b6d8becf94ad8980b056c6ff

commit_message:
Create and use subclass of sqlalchemy Query with soft_delete() method

Create subclass of sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query that has soft_delete() method

Change get_maker() method to create Session with our Query class

The main idea of soft_delete() method is to get good performance with clean
syntax: Let we have already `query` instance.

Clean syntax example:
If we want to make soft delete for each entry that correspond to query:
we should write:
        query.soft_delete()
instead of:
        query.update({
                deleted:True,
                'deleted_at': timeutils.utcnow(),
                'updated_at': literal_column('updated_at')})

Performance examples:
If we make:
        query.soft_delete()
we will make only one request to soft delete corresponding entries.
But if we make:
        for model_ref in query.all():
                model_ref.delete(session=session)
it will produce >= N + 1 queries.

In almost all situation it is better to use query.soft_delete() than
model.delete() method, because in second approach we should make
2 request (get model_ref and then soft delete it).

In future patch model.delete() will be at least renamed to model.soft_delete().
Probably it should be removed at all, to avoid situation in code with N+1
requests for soft deletion.

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: I6059982b83648133b6d8becf94ad8980b056c6ff

commit_message:
Move back api-v1 to the main api

API v2 is not finished and should only be optionnal. Move the binary as
api-v2 and remove the dep on pecan, only use it for tests.

This also fixes bug #1092227.

Change-Id: Ifaf0ad3918460bc2107e1563f0539695467a1856
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

to read and modify.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-17 15:37:08.000000000', 'message': "Make libvirt driver default to virtio for KVM/QEMU NICs

Currently users of KVM/QEMU must set libvirt_use_virtio_for_bridges
to true to get a virtio based NIC, instead of the awful rtl8139
that QEMU defaults to.

Switch libvirt_use_virtio_for_bridges to default to enabled, but
ensure it only takes effect if libvirt_type is 'kvm' or 'qemu'.

Although it is possible that some guest OS do not support virtio
drivers, currently Nova hardcodes use of 'virtio' for disks, so
this change doesn't make the current guest OS support situation
worse.

Obviously in the future, both NIC & disk models will have to be
made fully configurable

Change-Id: I7c0d306921f554ac2d06b5bdb1f9017ab7f9c643

commit_message:
Make libvirt driver default to virtio for KVM/QEMU NICs

Currently users of KVM/QEMU must set libvirt_use_virtio_for_bridges
to true to get a virtio based NIC, instead of the awful rtl8139
that QEMU defaults to.

Switch libvirt_use_virtio_for_bridges to default to enabled, but
ensure it only takes effect if libvirt_type is 'kvm' or 'qemu'.

Although it is possible that some guest OS do not support virtio
drivers, currently Nova hardcodes use of 'virtio' for disks, so
this change doesn't make the current guest OS support situation
worse.

Obviously in the future, both NIC & disk models will have to be
made fully configurable

Change-Id: I7c0d306921f554ac2d06b5bdb1f9017ab7f9c643
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
xenapi: Enhance devstack progress monitoring

Fixes bug 1091299

XenServer - devstack install monitors a log file by tailing it, to see,
if the devstack installation is finished. In some cases this script does
not detect, that the startup script is finished, and just waiting,
causing build failures with timeouts. With this change, the
install_os_domU script monitors, if the run.sh script is still running,
thus guaranteed to exit as soon as run.sh is done.

Change-Id: I24a7a46e93ce26be024096828c7954bc694af2b2

[{'created': '2012-12-18 14:36:17.000000000', 'message': 'Fix "image_meta" data passed in libvirt test cases

The helper methods _check_xml_and_disk_prefix,
_check_xml_and_disk_driver and _check_xml_and_disk_bus
all expect a disk image metadata dictionary as their first
parameter. Most callers were instead passing a instance
dictionary. The tests pass regardless, but passing the
right data avoids future developer confusion.

Change-Id: Ia594e8aa38a8627d304537c09d0d28a3e3a2b27b
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2012-12-18 23:22:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix "image_meta" data passed in libvirt test case

The helper method _check_xml_and_uuid expects a disk
image metadata dictionary as its first parameter. The
caller was instead passing a instance dictionary. The
tests pass regardless, but passing the right data
avoids future developer confusion.

Change-Id: Ia594e8aa38a8627d304537c09d0d28a3e3a2b27b
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix "image_meta" data passed in libvirt test case

The helper method _check_xml_and_uuid expects a disk
image metadata dictionary as its first parameter. The
caller was instead passing a instance dictionary. The
tests pass regardless, but passing the right data
avoids future developer confusion.

Change-Id: Ia594e8aa38a8627d304537c09d0d28a3e3a2b27b
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Refactor libvirt VIF classes to reduce duplicate code

Irrespective of the VIF driver used, some config parameters are
always identical (mac addr, NIC model). Move creation of the
vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestInterface instance into a base class,
so VIF driver impls only need to provide their custom data.

Change-Id: I7c9d5357c8ceff6d5eb2c982a7420bc93a7266bf
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-21 17:36:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix typo in image_utils tempfile handling

Commit cbcd340 changed from NamedTemporaryFile to mkstemp, but
mkstemp returns a file descripter, not a file object. We therefore
need to close the fd using os.close(). This was tested using
devstack.

Change-Id: I808fa470a141e249fe30ee762ee94f47ecfd3f63
'}]
commit_message:
Fix typo in image_utils tempfile handling

Commit cbcd340 changed from NamedTemporaryFile to mkstemp, but
mkstemp returns a file descripter, not a file object. We therefore
need to close the fd using os.close(). This was tested using
devstack.

Change-Id: I808fa470a141e249fe30ee762ee94f47ecfd3f63

commit_message:
Allow manual installation of packages.

Rather than force creation of an element for a single package install,
allow people to do this from the command line.

Change-Id: I63e2e7e50c4a7dbb8a8e198581dfadce91773621

commit_message:
Include English locale in base.

This change causes the "base" element to install and generate English
locales, thereby mitigating a lot of build noise (at least for
English speaking users). Also included is a note in the element's
README.md about what users in other locales should do.

Change-Id: I053c7e0254a0a0d7dde081f7cc72204a12aa8ef4

commit_message:
Move InputProxy to utils

This class is being used at least by Ceilometer in its Swift middleware, and
since it's a general one anyway, it looks good to move it to common.utils.

This is a follow-up to Chmouel suggestion in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18231

Change-Id: I8d0ed8600c4152b91be9a88a3b396c3967d0add2
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-19 17:16:10.000000000', 'message': 'Adding a means to connect back to a pydevd debugger.

That patch allows a developer to remotely run a pydev debugger and have the keystone-all process connect back to it.  The command line option --debug-url <host:port> enables this behavior.

Change-Id: I5bd0ad2e21055b3e6f8153a844f4269f358e54d6

commit_message:
Adding a means to connect back to a pydevd debugger.

That patch allows a developer to remotely run a pydev debugger and have the keystone-all process connect back to it.  The command line option --debug-url <host:port> enables this behavior.

Change-Id: I5bd0ad2e21055b3e6f8153a844f4269f358e54d6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-21 05:22:47.000000000', 'message': 'Makes sure to call crypto scripts with abspath

In some cases __file__ can return a local path instead of an
absolute path. For example when you are running with run_tests.sh
from a checkout that has been setup.py developed on os x. Make
sure that we convert it to an absolute path in case it is relative.

Change-Id: Ie18be6039db56601de18ce4ad48791b4abf118fe
'}]
commit_message:
Makes sure to call crypto scripts with abspath

In some cases __file__ can return a local path instead of an
absolute path. For example when you are running with run_tests.sh
from a checkout that has been setup.py developed on os x. Make
sure that we convert it to an absolute path in case it is relative.

Change-Id: Ie18be6039db56601de18ce4ad48791b4abf118fe

commit_message:
Add list-extensions capability to cinderclient.

Implements the list extension functionality from novaclient
written by harlowja (Change-Id: I5b72f5ea73c00f1c1a0f09f670d744c820e05837)

This provides a mechanism to view available extensions, and also
starts actually using the cinderclient contrib dir.

Original Author: harlowja

Change-Id: I4f9d04cb8a2aa05c978a2a5a926c9175ee3614bb

commit_message:
libvirt: Make vif_driver.plug() returns None

The return value of vif_driver.plug() was used only when nova wrote the
libvirt.xml file on initial boot of the instance. Make it returns None,
and add get_config() to get the configurations if needed.

If LibvirtBridgeDriver is used when the nova-comptue inits, we call
vif_driver.plug() without get the VIF configurations. By doing this
plug doesn't raise if the instance has not yet got a fixed-ip. Fixes
bug 1076309.

Change-Id: I0fafb3d98e3139bce0ef2cee04cab428a0621696

Looks like a good change.

Related thoughts though: If you own the images, you can specify PV vs HVM in Glance, so in that case you shouldn't really need this code. Is there something better we can do, if say pygrub on XenServer has a different version to that on DomU."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-12-20 11:08:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We can go down a long debate on how this could be done better; as for the first point you make, currently if you boot from an existing volume and you don't specify the image id, there's no way you can find out about the image unless you specify metadata some other way (and that's not currently supported); as for the version skew, not sure it can ever happen in practice; my take is that when you refresh your HV's, you refresh their domU's too; besides, thinking of relying on the pygrub installed on the XenServer defeats the whole point of streaming images via domU vs dom0 and thus offloading dom0 from doing expensive operations."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-12-20 11:22:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That clears it up: this is very useful for the boot from volume case.

Agreed, don't want to go into that debate, certainly not here.

I thought you always had to specify a glance image, which I always felt a bit odd anyway. Hopefully that will get sorted with glance's new multi-sourcing image thingy anyway."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-12-21 04:22:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Execute pygrub using nova-rootwrap in xenapi

Preserve the behavior where, if pygrub fails, compute attempts
to spawn the VM in HVM mode.

Fixes bug #1091628

Change-Id: Ia462964ebb1fc21d8e289de32557a2e7867f1257

Updates the Nova conductor API's ExceptionHelper class so that
it raises the previous exception instance instead of constructing
a new exception class based on the old one's message.

The motivation for this change is to enable testing of NovaException
message formatting. Previously this function would always construct
a new NovaException which had the incorrect (none) kwargs specified
to properly format the message. The exception would get thrown... but
it would cause extra LOG.error messages to appear in the log file due
to the formatting errors.

directly. From 'pydoc raise':

commit_message:
Raise old exception instance instead of new one.

Updates the Nova conductor API's ExceptionHelper class so that
it raises the previous exception instance instead of constructing
a new exception class based on the old one's message.

The motivation for this change is to enable testing of NovaException
message formatting. Previously this function would always construct
a new NovaException which had the incorrect (none) kwargs specified
to properly format the message. The exception would get thrown... but
it would cause extra LOG.error messages to appear in the log file due
to the formatting errors.

This commit works around the issue by raising the previous Exception
directly. From 'pydoc raise':

  If the first object is an instance, the type of the exception is the
  class of the instance, the instance itself is the value, and the
  second object must be ``None``.

Change-Id: I1dddc9e1e7e3d5f970baa9a34b709c943820295e

commit_message:
Update exceptions to pass correct kwargs.

Updates a variety of Nova exceptions so that they pass the correct
kwargs for proper exception message formatting. Previously
these exceptions would work but have incorrect error messages
because of how NovaException handled exception formatting errors.

Change-Id: I9601d3884a72d53a8ad742cf6610399968747cea

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-10-19 05:59:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So I'm wondering about the general approach here.

It's using /dev/urandom in the host to seed /dev/random in the guest. While not crypto secure of course, that would 
stop apps within the VM blocking on /dev/random.
Though you could just seed /dev/random
from /dev/urandom within the guest itself. I suppose
generally the host should have better entropy than
the (just booted) VM. Then again if there are many VMs,
then the entropy pool on the host may well be exhausted.

Another thing to consider is traditional hardware RNGs,
that would allow one to seed from /dev/random on the
host, rather than /dev/urandom.

Also with instruction level hardware RNGs in newer CPUS,
they're available within the VMs and so copying entropy
from /dev/urandom on the host may in fact reduce the
quality of /dev/random in the guests."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-10-22 16:02:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

First, 512bytes is too high. This is the entire size of the host's (default) entropy pool. You'll have immediate exhaustion on the host. A system really only needs to be seeded with 128 /bits/ of data, or 256 bits with a safety margin (check the manpage for random!).

However, I am worried that intentional calls to the metadata service to fetch new data could intentionally deplete the host's pool as part of an attack.

Entropy starvation on the host scares me a lot more than low entropy in the guests."}, {'account_id': 5906, 'date': '2012-10-22 19:55:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The host has access to "real hardware" and clearly has been running longer than a newly booted guest.  It certainly has at least the *opportunity* to have better entropy than a brand new, pristine, guest.

Scott's use of /dev/urandom is correct here.  We're using pseudorandomness in a non-blocking manner. The guest is simply using this to seed their own pseudorandom number generator.  This is leaps and bounds better than the current method, which just uses a seed that's bundled in the image itself.

Traditional RNGs are truly a wonderful thing, and will certainly help the physical host generate better entropy over time.  This is a way in which a host can supply the guest with a better seed for their own prng.

Contrary to what one previous reviewer said, this will *not* reduce the quality of /dev/random in the guest.  This information will simply be multiplex and hashed into Linux's entropy pool.  You cannot reduce the quality of entropy.  You could only not increase the pool.

Contrary to what another reviewer said, retrieving 512 bytes will absolutely *not* drain the host's entropy pool, since we're pulling this from /dev/urandom.  /dev/urandom is a limitless supply of pseudorandomness, which is perfectly appropriate in this case (seeding the guest's prng).

The quantity of 512 bytes was pulled from /etc/init.d/urandom, where a seed of 512 bytes is carried over across Linux reboots.  When an OpenStack guest boots for the first time, the /var/lib/urandom/random-seed contents are populated by the static value found in the public image.  In the case of a popular image, such as Ubuntu 64-bit, that can be a very common, well-known value.

The reviewer mentions the random.4 manpage...  Do go to the bottom of that manpage and you'll see in that documentation where it specifies how to carry a random seed across reboots.  And it does, in fact, recommend 512 bytes.  The other reference to 32 bytes (256 bits) is speaking specifically about /dev/random, and not the limitless /dev/urandom pool.

This change absolutely will *not* drain the entropy of the host.

I don't know that I have voting rights, but in any case, from a security and crypto professional standpoint, I'm +1 in favor of this change set.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-10-22 20:15:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

/dev/urandom is not EXACTLY limitless.  I was incorrect to say that it immediately depletes the pool. However, it DOES decrease the primary pool of entropy; refilled using data from the blocking /dev/random pool. Pulling too much, too frequently, from /dev/urandom will decrease the amount of entropy available to the host (and to the metadata service).

256bits is probably enough, but you're right that 4096bits are better, if we can afford them. When shutting down a host, they're plenty affordable. If we can afford them here, we should use the same value as well.

I found one reference that indicates each TCP-syn-cookie connection will eat 128bytes from the non-blocking pool.  In comparison, taking 512bytes might not be so bad."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-10-22 20:34:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This could be outdated... but here is a description of what it seems /dev/urandom currently does:
  http://www.gossamer-threads.com/lists/linux/kernel/850004#850004

Thus, if we pull 512 bytes, we'll get SOME of the contents of /dev/random up until twice the read wakeup threshold and then we'll get a PRNG.  Thus, we're somewhere in between "urandom is a good source of entropy" and "we're depleting /dev/random!"  If the above information is no longer correct, it would be good to get a source / reference for what urandom really does in current kernels.

Dustin, would be better to pull a more reasonable amount of data from /dev/random and run a /good/ PRNG against that such as FreeBSD does with Yarrow?'}, {'account_id': 5906, 'date': '2012-10-22 21:45:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Right, so /dev/urandom is limitless in that it will deliver pseudo random entropy in a non-blocking manner, as fast as the kernel can hash and mux the random pools.

You can benchmark your system like this:
kirkland@x220:~$ dd if=/dev/urandom of=/dev/null bs=1M count=1000
1048576000 bytes (1.0 GB) copied, 68.8496 s, 15.2 MB/s

My Thinkpad was able to serve up 1GB of /dev/urandom at 15.2 MB/s, which is pretty respectable, all things considered.

It would be trivial for us to change the 512 bytes to 32 bytes.  And I'm not opposed to that at all.  But in Ubuntu's initramfs scripts, we're just going to wget that metadata urandom URL 16 times, instead of once.

You are absolutely correct that every TCP connection open received by the kernel reads 128 bytes from /dev/urandom, which means that any remote user that can establish a TCP connection to your system can do the same thing we're doing here, by simply opening 4 TCP connections.  In fact, the guest's crawl of the metadata service alone sucks up far more bytes from the host than this single read.

Now all that said, none of this really matters, as long as we're talking about /dev/urandom.  That pool is inexhaustible and exists for precisely this reason.  If we were talking about /dev/random, that would be a totally different story.  It would be extremely "rude" for us to read anything more than 32 bytes from /dev/random, and extremely inadvisable to do that more than once in a very infrequent interval.  And such calls could block indefinitely.  This would be wrong, and my vote would have been -1, had this patch suggested that a guest drain the host's /dev/random pool.'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-10-22 21:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

in reguard to Eric's suggestion of using /dev/random, I explicitly chose 'urandom', and named it 'urandom'.  At some point we could also add a 'random' entry and even possibly make its appearance configurable.


However, I dont think it makes sense to pull "real random" and label it "urandom".  Nor do I think it makes sense to require /dev/random to have some entropy gathering daemon feed it in order to boot a guest.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-10-22 22:02:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Scott, I wasn't suggesting we pull those bytes from /dev/random - my point was that pulling from /dev/urandom actually decreases the pool of /dev/random faster than pulling directly from random and using a hashing function (this is what FreeBSD does internally, they have a single non-blocking interface to /dev/random and /dev/urandom)

Dustin - my point was largely that reading from /dev/urandom drains more of the /dev/random pool than one would generally presume. While urandom is inexhaustable, /dev/random is not, and we shouldn't drain it more than necessary.

Every 512byte read from /dev/urandom (by default) seems to pull up to 384bytes from /dev/random. As I understand it, following every read, we'll be left with 128bytes of entropy in /dev/random.

Because this could have potentially severe consequences, I wanted to make sure this change was throughly considered. Based on the behaviors of TCP, however, I think it should be satisfactory to pull relatively large amounts from urandom...

I'm ready to put a +1 on this, but I'd ideally like to see broader analysis."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-10-22 22:16:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Paraphrasing my 3 questions...

In the general case is seeding from the host any better than
just seeding within the VM itself, since the VM should have
some entropy based on timers etc?

In the presence of traditional hardware RNGs, one might
prefer to seed from /dev/random on the host rather than
hardcoding os.urandom() and precluding this source?

In the presence of instruction level hardware RNGs in newer
CPUS, since they're available within the VMs, doesn't 
introducing "entropy" from /dev/urandom on the host in fact
reduce the quality of /dev/random in the VMs?

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-10-23 04:09:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

p-draigbrady: When using rng-tools with a hRNG, /dev/urandom will be ultimately feed from this source. Intel even seems to recommend this.

You'd still want to increase the poolsize here, since after 384-bytes you might start using the PRNG. The poolsize would allow more random bytes to get buffered from the hRNG.

Reading fewer than 384-bytes and a hardware-rng, you should find even /dev/urandom to be a pretty good source of entropy with default kernel settings."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-10-23 05:03:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

"In the general case is seeding from the host any better than just seeding within the VM itself, since the VM should have some entropy based on timers etc?"

On shutdown, available random data in /dev/random is saved in /var/lib/urandom/random-seed.  Then, on boot that is appended to /dev/urandom [1].   The intent is to add some more unpredictability early in boot (assuming normal early boot has little entropy).  However, For a new instance the contents of /var/lib/urandom/random-seed are possibly known to a wide audience (anyone who wants to read public images).

Some do not trust the randomness generated by boot in a vm.  Using the data, from outside the vm, each instance's boot has 512 bytes of [u]randomness that is at very least hard to predict and virtually guaranteed to differ between even between 2 identical vms on the same host.

Its labelled 'urandom'.
--
[1] http://bazaar.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-branches/ubuntu/raring/sysvinit/raring/view/head:/debian/src/initscripts/etc/init.d/urandom'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-10-23 09:03:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the info guys.

Just stating some facts for my own reference:

* headless servers generally don't have much entropy
* reading /dev/urandom quickly reduces entropy available
* so does starting processes on Linux due to address space randomization (hence use simple scripts with a loop to inspect /proc/sys/kernel/random/entropy_avail)

I found the 2 articles here informative:
http://strugglers.net/~andy/blog/2010/06/06/adventures-in-entropy-part-1/"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-10-24 11:53:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

question about date versions being used inline. Mostly informational.'}, {'account_id': 5906, 'date': '2012-10-24 15:26:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That's roughly the date of the next OpenStack release, which would be the point at which this metadata service API becomes frozen/stable."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-10-24 15:41:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

ok, in past it looks like the metadata versions lined up more with change drops vs. release dates, right? What happens if there is another metadata change between now and release? For teams following trunk that seems like it might break them.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-10-24 21:03:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

I want to reopen this.  The urandom/metadata functionality is sound and helps anneal entropy in guest VMs.  The current objection (about the metadata API version) is conflating the issue and should be a separate thread.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-06 14:51:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

it should be reopenned. But you can't deal with the meta data versioning issue separate from the patch. :)

I'd be +1 if we stayed consistent on past versioning systems for metadata server."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-11-06 16:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Sean,

| "@scott I think that's enough of a change in the way we version the
| metadata server that it requires some broader discussion. There are lots
| of folks following trunk (probably crazy, but it's our community), so
| I'd rather not set up a breaking situation for them given that we didn't
| only version the metadata on releases previously."

| "I'd be +1 if we stayed consistent on past versioning systems for
| metadata server."

I'm not sure what exactly you were suggesting.  There realy is no "past
versioning system" for the metadata server.  I created a YYYY-MM-DD
based one towards the end of Folsom, and randomly chose a date close to
when I did the proposal. That was in keeping with the EC2 metadata
versioning convention.  I personally find it sufficient.

The reason we don't want to arbitrarily add additional versions exposed
in the MD is that currently we'd have to copy those to the config drive
also.  I don't find it useful to have:
 2012-11-06/meta-data.js
 2012-11-21/meta-data.js
 2012-11-22/meta-data.js
 latest/meta-data.js # (same as 2012-11-22)

each with data inside differing only by addition or removal of a single
item.

My solution for this was to open up the new YYYY-MM-DD that matched the
release date of the product.  I'd even be willing to not apply the
"latest" link for a YYYY-MM-DD until after a release, but that requires
a "cleanup" change right before release, which I hoped to avoid.

Instead, what I suggest is:
 a. consumer applications should generally be forgiving on missing content
 b. consumer applications should use a specific YYYY-MM-DD that
    represents a date not in the future.
 c. OpenStack adds a new YYYY-MM-DD entry matching the expected date of
    the next release.

  If date slips, then we have some issue here, i agree with 'c'.   If
you have another proposal, I'm not opposed to listening. But be aware
that there is user exposed "cost" to different entries in metadata
service and on the config drive in terms of space and pointless
duplication.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-06 16:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The issue is there are plenty of people that are using OpenStack not on release boundaries, including one of the biggest public OpenStack deployments (Rackspace). I think we should be really cautious of breaking them, which we would do if 2013-04-04 represents multiple types of content. 

I think this probably something to take at the list at this point, and get the discussion going there, because we should probably have a policy on metadata versioning here.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-08 05:01:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

RAX currently doesn't use metadata but the point is important. I propose we call the version 'experimental' until the actual release. We can replace it with the release date of the grizzly release when it comes out."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-18 19:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Restored'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-18 19:37:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-18 20:01:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-18 20:19:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I know this has been discussed earlier, but I'm still not exactly comfortable with this proposal from a security POV. Upstream QEMU recently added support for a virtio-rng device. In the course of design discussions for this, the consensus emerged that using /dev/urandom on the host, to feed the guest entropy is categorically a wrong thing todo. To quote 

   http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2012-10/msg05174.html

  "First of all, feeding /dev/urandom to the guest is dangerous -- you are feeding it PRNG contents but telling it that it is real entropy. This is a security hole."

The eventual design QEMU settled on was to allow feeding virtio-rng either from /dev/random, or from the EGD daemon (https://egd.sourceforge.net) and *not* /dev/urandom. QEMU also allows VMs to be rate-limited in how much they can consume from the random source.

Second, whatever we do for config driver here, IMHO, it should be configurable. That way if we configure a guest to use virtio-rng (or equiv) we're not needlessly wasting host entropy populating this config driver data which won't be required there.'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-18 20:45:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

"you are feeding it PRNG contents but telling it that it is real entropy. This is a security hole."

I agree with this.  However, that has basically no relevance here.  Calling 'urandom' as 'random' is bad.  Calling 'urandom' 'urandom' is not.

If it were, then there is a massive security hole in linux named '/dev/urandom'.  If something uses this, they're as knowledgeable that it is 'urandom' as anyone opening /dev/urandom.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-18 22:34:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I agree with this. However, that has basically no relevance here. 

The relevance really depends on what the intended purpose / use-case of this config drive 'urandom' data is, which isn't clearly stated in the commit message here. On the surface it appears to be intended for seeding the guest random number generator. If so, I believe my comment is indeed relevant here. If not, please describe what the intended use case is for this data."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-19 02:27:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The key point in your argument was that presenting psuedo random data from the host as random data to the guest was a security issue.

That is basically the same as tricking gpg's insistence on /dev/random by doing:
 rm -f /dev/random
 ln -s /dev/urandom /dev/random

Yes, it is bad.

We are very explicitly *not* doing that.  We are presenting 512 bytes of psuedo random data from the host to the guest and as *psuedo random data*.

The guest's use of it is really irrelevant.  Yes, some guests will seed their randomness with this data.  For guests that unlimited true random data via some other mechanism then this wont really hurt anything.  Either it wont make things worse or they wont use it.

I would completely agree with your argument if the field were labelled 'random'."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-19 09:56:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> The guest's use of it is really irrelevant. Yes, some guests will seed their 
> randomness with this data. For guests that unlimited true random data via 
> some other mechanism then this wont really hurt anything. Either it wont make
> things worse or they wont use it.

I'm sorry, the intended usage of this data is *very* relevant to the review.

Without knowing what the intended usage that motivated this feature, how can we reasonably evaluate whether this is the best solution to the problem ? For example, if it is intended as a way to let guests seed their entropy pool, then it is quite possible that a better solution would be to provide real random data from /dev/random or an EGD, instead of this urandom data, or possibly in addition/parallel to it.

I don't agree with your assertion that it won't make things worse. Just calling it 'urandom' and then saying its the guest admin's fault if they mis-use it is really not satisfactory. We can not expect that guest sysadmins will understand the implications of feeding "urandom" into their guest's /dev/random - those that don't understand will be given a false sense of security imagining they have a good RNG in their guest. As such I believe this *would* be making things worse, because guest admins will be misled.

Further, if the guests are not using this data, then it is also bad from the host POV, because we are uneccesarily consuming host entropy which may cause /dev/urandom to degrade to pure CSRNG mode when it otherwise would not need to.'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-19 13:59:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Is psuedo random data the ideal solution for *any* problem?  Probably not.

If /dev/random was infinite, then there would be no question.  We'd use it for the source of this data.  We'd name it 'random' and be done.  If /dev/random was infinite, there would be no /dev/urandom.

We're essentially copying a widely deployed and accepted mechanism by providing psuedo random data and calling it that."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-19 14:53:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> If /dev/random was infinite, then there would be no question. We'd use it
> for the source of this data. We'd name it 'random' and be done. If 
> /dev/random was infinite, there would be no /dev/urandom.

Even though /dev/random is finite, this doesn't rule out its use as an entropy source for guests. It is possible to use it if you apply rate limiting on the amount of entropy that can be provided per guest, or perhaps per tenant. As mentioned earlier it is also possible to obtain entropy from an external entropy gathering daemon, of which there are several choices.

> We're essentially copying a widely deployed and accepted mechanism by providing psuedo random data and calling it that.

What name we give the field is not what I'm debating. Given the data source you chose to use, the name you chose is perfectly correct. My questions are solely around the intended usage of this data, and whether we can do something else which is better suited to the use case being targeted.

Since the debate on this patch doesn't seem to be going anywhere productive, I think it would be beneficial to create a blueprint outlining what OpenStack needs to achieve wrt providing guest instances entropy, and the various options for satisfying these goals."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-19 15:05:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Daniel,
 2 thoughts came to my mind.
a.) are you aware that at least Ubuntu and Debian and RHEL already use /dev/urandom data from one boot to seed it for the next?  Given that fact, we're most certainly not making this any worse, as a published AMI has a known value stored that it will seed its random with, and we're giving another *unknown* value as a source.
b.) To address your concerns about mis-use of 'urandom', would those concerns be alleviated if the field was named 'random-seed'?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-19 17:03:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> 2 thoughts came to my mind.
> a.) are you aware that at least Ubuntu and Debian and RHEL already use /dev/urandom data
>     from one boot to seed it for the next?  Given that fact, we're most certainly not
>     making this any worse, as a published AMI has a known value stored that it will seed
>     its random with, and we're giving another *unknown* value as a source.

Ok, so there's two different issues at play here

 - How do we seed the guest RNG
 - How do we provide entropy to the guest RNG

The seed of the RNG does not have to be cryptographically secure, since it does not add entropy to the RNG, merely mixes its initial state. Thus using some urandom data from the host to seed the guest RNG, to get around the issue of a baked-in random-seed from the image, is fine. Using urandom data to provide entropy for the guest RNG though is wrong.

I see now that you're probably only thinking about this in terms of the initial RNG seed. You are right that having a /var/lib/random-seed file in a distributed image is bad, because VMs will have predictable initial state on their first boot. If it is a instance backed by persistent volumes, this is first-boot problem only though - on subsequent boots the /var/lib/random-seed will be fine.

> b.) To address your concerns about mis-use of 'urandom', would those concerns be
>     alleviated if the field was named 'random-seed'?

Yes, that would make some sense, however, using the config-drive / metadata service seems sub-optimal (and at the same time overkill), because every person building images needs to make sure they've set their images up to actually use this data we're providing. IMHO a simpler solution to populating the random seed would be to just use Nova's file injection code to replace the /var/lib/random-seed file contents in the guest image, with fresh data. This would easily fit into Nova's framework for file injection with little effort.

As for actually providing real entropy to the guest RNG, that's a broader topic, which can be dealt with separately from the RNG seed."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-19 17:59:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

guest injection is error prone and generally un-advisable.  At best it sometimes works, at worst it destroys a user's data.

The general direction is to remove it *entirely*.

I'll change the key name to be 'random-seed'."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-12-19 18:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Also guest injection means that openstack actually "touches the innards of said guest image". This seems to break a lot of abstraction concepts where the image should not be messed with from the outside. 

Just a few reasons I can think of.

1. Said image may want to handle said manipulation itself or in a slightly different manner (do some advanced processing before writing said file), with guest injection it doesn't even have the option/capability (since someone else messed with its innards)
2. New or older operating system being created as an image may not be detectable by said filesystem injection, and thus injection may write to an incorrect location. Said image likely knows where to place said files using its own "local" knowledge/code to do so. Ie add support for "amiga image", it may have a concept of /dev/urandom/seed or whatever, but it may be in a completely different location, it should decide that location, not some external entity that may/may not get it right.
...'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-19 18:15:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> guest injection is error prone and generally un-advisable. At best it sometimes works, at worst it destroys a user's data.

I don't buy this. If injection is only done when initially booting the instance from an image, you're not destroying anything - the image is fresh out of glance. It'd only be dangerous if done to a instance using persistent volumes, on the non-initial boot.

I believe injection code is actually better in this case, because it will work for a potentially wider range of images by virtue of not needing the image to be modified for this openstack specific metadata item.

I actually see both file injection & config-drive methods co-existing, because I don't believe either impl can provide complete enough coverage for populating random-seed for all the types of images that users want to run. I'd suggest a metadata tag against images be used to allow person uploading to indicate which random-seed population method they like, along with a Nova level config option to indicate which methods should be tried in absence of a image specific tag."}, {'account_id': 4303, 'date': '2012-12-19 18:35:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> > guest injection is error prone and generally un-advisable. At best it sometimes works, at worst it destroys a user's data.

> I don't buy this. If injection is only done when initially booting the instance from an image, you're not destroying anything - the image is fresh out of glance. It'd only be dangerous if done to a instance using persistent volumes, on the non-initial boot.

Fresh out of glance doesn't mean much when your users can upload their own images."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-20 13:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 14:01:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 23:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 5906, 'date': '2012-12-21 00:09:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

On Thu, Dec 20, 2012 at 5:08 PM, Michael Still (Code Review) <review@openstack.org> wrote:
> Michael Still has posted comments on this change.
>
> Change subject: add 'random_seed' entry to instance metadata
>
>
> Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved
>
> We've historically had security problems with injection -- especially with images from glance (think symlinks). I'd like to see us stop doing it entirely.

Yeah, I actually dislike the injection suggestion for a different reason...

With Scott's current implementation, each read of the urandom interface from metadata will yield different results, which actually implements the Hiesenberg Uncertainty Principle for entropic purposes -- that value changes each and every time its read.

With injection, it would actually be easy/trivial to *see* the initial seed by just reading that file any time after boot.  By having it generated ephemerally, it makes it impossible for future readers to know the initial seed.

-- 
:-Dustin"}]

commit_message:
add 'random_seed' entry to instance metadata

This adds a 'random_seed' entry to the openstack metadata for an instance, both
in config-drive and in metadata service.  It is a 512 byte blob of base64
encoded random data.

In the metadata service, every call will result in new data.

The intent of this field is to add some entropy to an instances entropy pool.

Change-Id: I7d8c1f9bf70a9c5a54f6349f3277588553471555

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-06 07:23:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix revert resize failure with disk.local not found

If we resize an instance from a flavor without ephemeral disk to a flavor
with it, it resizes OK, but if we revert this resize, the instance fail to
spawn with error disk.local not found.
The reason is that the libvirt driver get the wrong resized flavor from
instance, so the flavor info of instance should be updated before instance
spawns.

Fixes: bug #1086688

Change-Id: I2c54586803c60baab7f20297b309a8e6c4134d13
'}, {'created': '2012-12-07 04:44:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fix revert resize failure with disk.local not found

If we resize an instance from a flavor without ephemeral disk to a flavor
with it, it resizes OK, but if we revert this resize, the instance fail to
spawn with error disk.local not found.
The reason is that the libvirt driver get the wrong resized flavor from
instance, so the flavor info of instance should be updated before instance
spawns.

Fixes: bug #1086688

Change-Id: I2c54586803c60baab7f20297b309a8e6c4134d13

instance, so the flavor info of instance should be updated before instance
spawns.

Fixes: bug #1086688

Change-Id: I2c54586803c60baab7f20297b309a8e6c4134d13

commit_message:
Fix revert resize failure with disk.local not found

If we resize an instance from a flavor without ephemeral disk to a flavor
with it, it resizes OK, but if we revert this resize, the instance fail to
spawn with error disk.local not found.
The reason is that the libvirt driver get the wrong resized flavor from
instance, so the flavor info of instance should be updated before instance
spawns.

Fixes: bug #1086688

Change-Id: I2c54586803c60baab7f20297b309a8e6c4134d13

For the case when backdoor_port is None for a service, then the

Change-Id: I0fad967f94b9d9928e9134fe5901d5e256b6ab69
'}]
commit_message:
Fix _find_ports() for when backdoor_port is None.

For the case when backdoor_port is None for a service, then the
backdoor_port configuration option was not set for that service.
Instead of failing for this case, just skip establishing a backdoor
connection to services without a backdoor_port, and move on to the
other services.

Change-Id: I0fad967f94b9d9928e9134fe5901d5e256b6ab69

commit_message:
Add extension to allow hiding of addresses

* Servers in certain states will have network_info but it may change,
  (eg. rescheduled build on another host). The extension allows the
  operator to hide the address information in those states
* Fixes bug LP 1089092

Change-Id: Ie843e34a41c77903b201b45c5b67a6f75334cb5e

commit_message:
Volume backed live migration w/o shared storage

This patch allows live migration of volume backed instances without
the need for shared storage (For Libvirt only).

Fixes LP Bug #1074054
DocImpact

Change-Id: If7abd63a610a44720cec2d4021cc4ee737ea301d

commit_message:
Make sure we don't double remove tmp on exception

The fetch_to_raw code would fail if an exception is thrown during
fetch because it would attempt to delete the same file twice.

Fix this by using mkstemp and our wrapper which only deletes the
tmp file if it exists.

Change-Id: I7bb3171d3c7dc023fc743578c2ce6e804bbc49f5

commit_message:
Parameterize database connection in test.py

Make more of the db connection options into parameters instead of CONF
values so that they behave better when testing multiple DB back-ends,
as with the baremetal driver.

Change-Id: Ib122b86ded4bce430773c36fdb5f85bb71100d3d

commit_message:
Add --os-cacert

Add support to specify a ca certificate bundle to verify
keystone TLS (https) certificates.  This only verifies
certificates on the keystone connection, swift https
connections are unchanged.

Change-Id: I14351b405af4fd3d1970ba6656c1282a5d0a1082

Looks reasonable. What testing has been done now?'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-12-20 12:10:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Not sure, I understand your question; other than unit testing and downstream functional testing, I see no other way you can test this stuff...that's how it broke in the first place ;)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-12-20 12:12:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

Did this functionality ever work with the xenapi driver? If so, when did it regress?

I ask because if it never worked, then you're essentially adding a new feature. That might be acceptable if the patch was small and low risk, but it looks quite tricky and the type of thing that could cause existing, working functionality to regress.

See http://wiki.openstack.org/StableBranch for how we want the stable branch to be a "safe source of high-impact bug fixes"

Marking as -2 for now. If you can show how the functionality worked in a previous release and regressed in Folsom I could be persuaded to change.

Thanks for the interest in the stable branch, though!'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-12-20 13:26:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I guess it could be considered a new feature or a fix for an Folsom feature, depending on how you look at it.

Boot from volume for XenAPI was added here:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/xenapi-boot-from-volume

It turns out it only worked with XenAPI NFS style volumes rather than iSCSI volumes, as was intended, now people have started testing that code properly. For XenAPI, those are the only two possible types of volumes.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-12-20 13:30:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Armando, sorry my question was unclear. I meant to ask: Did you test both XenSM and iSCSI volumes when you tested your change?'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-12-20 19:30:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Mark, I cannot answer your question for sure, but I think it worked during the Folsom timeframe.

The patchset is actually rather trivial (for the trained eye, of course), and it's mainly unit tests to ensure that the existing functionality does not break.

If you want to err on the side of caution, then this patch would need to be abandoned. I can provide a patch on the bug report, in case people (who are using Folsom stable) stumble upon this and want a fix.

I was only being a good citizen."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-12-20 19:30:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

John: I tested the iscsi path. Mate (who reviewed the Grizzly fix) tested the XenSM path.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-12-20 22:14:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-07 22:49:42.000000000', 'message': "Fixes KeyError: 'sr_uuid' when booting from volume on xenapi

This change fixes the capability for a XenServer/XCP hypervisor
to boot instances from an iscsi volume running on Cinder.

This patch takes into account that Cinder can be configured
with an iscsi back-end, instead of a xensm one, where keys like
sr_uuid are not being specified. It works through the magic of
determining the SR, and the vdi associated with the iscsi target
and lun.

This patch also does a bit of clean-up of code/comments that no
longer apply.

Since Folsom and Grizzly have diverged a little bit as far as
the xenapi virt driver is concerned, this change cannot be a
straight cherry-pick from the Grizzly fix.

Addresses bug/1087308

Grizzly review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17726/

Change-Id: I059b5a9660c321c09a27b0dc060da64067609294
"}, {'created': '2012-12-07 22:50:48.000000000', 'message': "Fixes KeyError: 'sr_uuid' when booting from volume on xenapi

This change fixes the capability for a XenServer/XCP hypervisor
to boot instances from an iscsi volume running on Cinder.

with an iscsi back-end, instead of a xensm one, where keys like
sr_uuid are not being specified. It works through the magic of
determining the SR, and the vdi associated with the iscsi target
and lun.

straight cherry-pick from the Grizzly fix.

commit_message:
Fixes KeyError: 'sr_uuid' when booting from volume on xenapi

This change fixes the capability for a XenServer/XCP hypervisor
to boot instances from an iscsi volume running on Cinder.

This patch takes into account that Cinder can be configured
with an iscsi back-end, instead of a xensm one, where keys like
sr_uuid are not being specified. It works through the magic of
determining the SR, and the vdi associated with the iscsi target
and lun.

This patch also does a bit of clean-up of code/comments that no
longer apply.

Since Folsom and Grizzly have diverged a little bit as far as
the xenapi virt driver is concerned, this change cannot be a
straight cherry-pick from the Grizzly fix.

Addresses bug 1087308

Grizzly review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17726/

Change-Id: I059b5a9660c321c09a27b0dc060da64067609294

commit_message:
Add doc for configuring keystone SSL support

fixes bug 1032788

Keystone SSL support was re-added in folsom. This adds a new section
under the identity management chapter explaining how to configure it.

Patchset minor spell fix and markup plus a sample with pathnames.

Change-Id: I4c23f04cfeae3a90a33dd3f324ddc85c95669721

commit_message:
Update OS_PASSWORD to match keystone scripted inst

fixes bug 1083674

As noted in the bug report, there is a mismatch between the password
used in the keystone scripted install, and the rest of the documentation.

So if you used the scripted install, various steps will fail.

Since it's simpler to change the documentation and the choice of this
variable is arbitary - update the docs.

Patchset rebases against master.

Change-Id: I05e8268637e8572aadc8b274047b392d8c7aba75

commit_message:
Replace deprecated keystone cli arguments

The code examples for creating and users and endpoints uses the
deprecated --os-token and --os-endpoint arguments. These have
been replaced with --token and --endpoint, respectively.

Fixes bug #1092383

Change-Id: I56b88e0057cb2c54d507b72235bc5ad567da3f78

commit_message:
Add security groups configuration to allow accesses to VMs.

Fixes bug 1082990

This commit contains minor clean up of command line options
and tunes column width of some tables to make it easier to read.

Patch fixes bug 1092619 also while we're updating.
Patch clears up a few incorrect linkend="xml:id" references.

Change-Id: I9269a1ceaa04ff8a58c3e40d7442ad00b4286c44

subject: Fixes console logging with non-swift middleware
messages:
[{'account_id': 597, 'date': '2012-12-20 00:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Oh, brother, I knew something like that would come up with that premature return. Just could not imagine what. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 00:22:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/check/gate-swift-docs/1095 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/1238 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/check/gate-swift-python26/1343 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/check/gate-swift-python27/1345 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/23121 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-12-20 07:58:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Works well, tested with a fresh devstack install.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-12-20 19:26:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

So we don't seem to setup a root logger near as I can tell.

So anyone that calls logging.getLogger(__name__) if __name__ doesn't start with swift they're sorta not gunna have a good time.

So fine, we add a config option to keystone so that *it* can log under our namespace:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+bug/1089664

But then we *also* have our Formatter *real* careful about records coming from unadapted loggers.

Last time I had to make this work I think my Formatter would check if the record is in my apps namespace (i.e. record.name.startswith('swift')) and have a early return with a simple basic format potentially un-adapted records.  But since you can't log at all unless you *are* under the swift namespace it's a bit of a catch 22 here.

Bummer."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 20:26:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://zuul.openstack.org/'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-12-20 20:26:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

This already had the requisite pair of +2s, but no Approved.

Also, this looks entirely reasonable. I'm not familiar with keystoneclient's middleware's logging setup, but this change doesn't look like it'll break anything."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 21:40:03.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 21:40:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/gate/gate-swift-docs/1100 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/gate/gate-swift-pep8/1243 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/gate/gate-swift-python26/1348 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/gate/gate-swift-python27/1350 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18446/1/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/23262 : SUCCESS
'}]

commit_message:
Fixes console logging with non-swift middleware

Fixes logging if logging to the console with non-swift middleware (such
as keystone) enabled.  This also fixes issues with swift in devstack

Change-Id: Ib8b691b62b657a6d4ecdb1648d1fc2f3a0479982

commit_message:
Add support for user groups

This documents the v3 api changes proposed to represent support
for groups of users in keystone.  These changes match the
origional spec that was part of the blueprint.

blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/user-groups

DocImpact

Change-Id: I48d874ce5b5019e5ddee56c9b9b73a796b2cbdff

commit_message:
Use requests module for HTTP/HTTPS

* Implement correct certificate verification
* Add --os-cacert
* Rework tests for requests

Pinned requests module to < 1.0 as 1.0.2 is now current in pipi
as of 17Dec2012.

Blueprint: tls-verify

Change-Id: I9a25a94c8dfcaf483c4c8328439809d65cf10b38

pylint errors:

File nova/virt/baremetal/tilera.py
Line 261:            open_ip = base64.b64decode(user_data)
E0602: Undefined variable 'base64'
File nova/virt/baremetal/tilera.py
Line 288:        var = self.baremetal_nodes.define_vars(instance, None, None)
E1101: Instance of 'TILERA' has no 'baremetal_nodes' member"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-08-15 13:58:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think it would be good to move all baremetal configuration options into a separate group, but I'd be happy to submit a patch to do that after folsom-3

e.g.

 opts = [
     cfg.BoolOpt('baremetal_inject_password', ...),
 ]
 FLAGS.register_opts(opts, group='baremetal')

then in nova.conf

 [DEFAULT]
 ...

 [baremetal]
 inject_password=False

and in the code:

        if not FLAGS.baremetal.inject_password:
            admin_password = None"}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-08-15 14:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-08-15 15:04:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Yun Mao: Thanks for pointing out pylint errors. Fixed.
@Mark McLoughlin: Thanks for good suggestion.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-15 15:06:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

@Devananda
We change code to use more db functionality, thanks.

As for images, we use images in Glance already. The images are downloaded from Glance, then delivered to bare-metal nodes via pxe or bm_deploy_server. (please check inline comment too)'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2012-08-21 17:05:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-14 17:02:13.000000000', 'message': 'Updated bare-metal provisioning framework to use MySQL DB and PXE support.

Part 3 of 5: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

Bare-metal provisioning is extended to use a MySQL database and
to support various plug-ins such as PXE.
Driver, domain management, and back-end (non-PXE) tilera code are updated.
This patch includes the tilera(non-PXE) back-end and the PXE back-end.
IPMI back-end is also added.

Change-Id: I55617a8da52d20d4df727b8bbde8e5f72d3bf130
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
'}, {'created': '2012-08-14 17:23:54.000000000', 'message': 'Updated bare-metal provisioning framework.

Bare-metal provisioning is extended to use a MySQL and
to support various plug-ins such as PXE.
Driver and domain management codes are updated.
This patch includes only the tilera(non-PXE) back-end.
The documents describe how to install and configure bare-metal
nova-compute to support non-PXE (tilera) back-end nodes.
It includes the packages needed for installation, how to create
a bare-metal instance type, how to register bare-metal nodes and NIC,
and how to run an instance. Nova flags for the configuration of
bare-metal nova-compute are described.
Now one bare-metal driver initially registers multiple entries of bare-metal
nodes. It periodically reports the capabilities of the multiple bare-metal
nodes and reports it as a list of capabilities.

Change-Id: I55617a8da52d20d4df727b8bbde8e5f72d3bf130
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

nova-compute to support non-PXE (tilera) back-end nodes.
It includes the packages needed for installation, how to create
a bare-metal instance type, how to register bare-metal nodes and NIC,
and how to run an instance. Nova flags for the configuration of
bare-metal nova-compute are described.
Now one bare-metal driver initially registers multiple entries of bare-metal
nodes. It periodically reports the capabilities of the multiple bare-metal
nodes and reports it as a list of capabilities.

Change-Id: I55617a8da52d20d4df727b8bbde8e5f72d3bf130
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
DocImpact: adds bare-metal-tilera docs

commit_message:
New Baremetal provisioning framework.

This is a minimal patch for the new baremetal driver.

With this driver, nova compute registers multiple entries of baremetal
nodes. It periodically updates the capabilities of the multiple
baremetal nodes and reports it as a list of capabilities.

It does not include Tilera or PXE back-ends, which will be provided
by subsequent patches. It also does not include VIF or volume components.

Part 4 of 7: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

Change-Id: I55617a8da52d20d4df727b8bbde8e5f72d3bf130
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
Co-authored-by: Chris Krelle <NobodyCam@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Devananda van der Veen <devananda.vdv@gmail.com>

subject: Move baremetal database tests to fixtures.

commit_message:
Move baremetal database tests to fixtures.

The baremetal database tests didn't get migrated to fixtures when we migrated
base nova. Funny story: maybe we should re-use code rather than copying!

So I did that. It's reusable now.

Change-Id: I730aad4a6aedb3993e032a14c9b8d2cd58913b4f

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-20 00:21:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix a test isolation error in compute.test_compute.

In the compute.test_compute tests the common notifier_api
test_notifier was being used. However, to use it correctly
requires that any existing drivers be reset, otherwise the
newly configured notifier does not take effect.

I converted the other call sites that were doing this to
also use cleanups rather than teardowns to reset it after
usage, which got rid of two boilerplate tearDown methods.

Change-Id: I6573d4652bb96dcebf38ef17d429d47d8a0e6434
'}]
commit_message:
Fix a test isolation error in compute.test_compute.

In the compute.test_compute tests the common notifier_api
test_notifier was being used. However, to use it correctly
requires that any existing drivers be reset, otherwise the
newly configured notifier does not take effect.

I converted the other call sites that were doing this to
also use cleanups rather than teardowns to reset it after
usage, which got rid of two boilerplate tearDown methods.

Change-Id: I6573d4652bb96dcebf38ef17d429d47d8a0e6434

[{'created': '2012-12-18 19:43:10.000000000', 'message': "Specify some arguments by name.

'nova boot', 'nova flavor-key', 'nova flavor-show' and the other subcommands
can be specified by a flavor name also.
But 'nova flavor-delete' and 'nova list --flavor' cannot, also 'nova list
--image' cannot be specified by a image name.
I feel it is user-friendly that a user can specify arguments by name.

By this patch, a user can do it like the following.

Before appying this patch:
 $ nova flavor-delete m1.tiny
 ERROR: Flavor m1.tiny could not be found. (HTTP 404) (Request-ID: req-af2c049f-1b77-42cf-a9ed-a3914626bc83)
 $
 $ nova list --flavor m1.tiny
 ERROR: Flavor could not be found (HTTP 422) (Request-ID: req-dbfd5df2-77d7-4a71-a3e6-b1f7fd25b96c)

 $ nova list --image cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-uec

After appying this patch:
 $ nova flavor-delete m1.tiny

 $ nova list --flavor m1.tiny
 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+

 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+

 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 $

 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+

 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+

 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 $

Fixes bug 1091814

Change-Id: Ic7f6ce76608a448dea3c151bc349391fbf3fa456
"}]
commit_message:
Specify some arguments by name.

'nova boot', 'nova flavor-key', 'nova flavor-show' and the other subcommands
can be specified by a flavor name also.
But 'nova flavor-delete' and 'nova list --flavor' cannot, also 'nova list
--image' cannot be specified by a image name.
I feel it is user-friendly that a user can specify arguments by name.

By this patch, a user can do it like the following.

Before appying this patch:
 $ nova flavor-delete m1.tiny
 ERROR: Flavor m1.tiny could not be found. (HTTP 404) (Request-ID: req-af2c049f-1b77-42cf-a9ed-a3914626bc83)
 $
 $ nova list --flavor m1.tiny
 ERROR: Flavor could not be found (HTTP 422) (Request-ID: req-dbfd5df2-77d7-4a71-a3e6-b1f7fd25b96c)
 $
 $ nova list --image cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-uec

 $

After appying this patch:
 $ nova flavor-delete m1.tiny
 $
 $ nova list --flavor m1.tiny
 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 | ID                                   | Name   | Status | Networks         |
 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 | 2f003e0e-bfdf-4f56-bdf9-276732e640a0 | test01 | ACTIVE | private=10.0.0.2 |
 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 $
 $ nova list --image cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-uec
 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 | ID                                   | Name   | Status | Networks         |
 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 | 2f003e0e-bfdf-4f56-bdf9-276732e640a0 | test01 | ACTIVE | private=10.0.0.2 |
 +--------------------------------------+--------+--------+------------------+
 $

Fixes bug 1091814

Change-Id: Ic7f6ce76608a448dea3c151bc349391fbf3fa456

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-20 15:45:49.000000000', 'message': 'run_tests.sh fixup venv/novenv logic

The section which prompts y/n for creating a new venv can never be
reached with any combination of CLI options (since always_venv=0 and
never_venv=0 can never happen simultaneously)

This actually makes the --no-virtual-env option pointless, so we may
as well remove it and explicitly set it as the default (it was anyway
previously but by virtue of the never_venv option being undefined)

Change-Id: I3c803533fda55a6814b7536b5c1328312acd3d57
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
run_tests.sh fixup venv/novenv logic

The section which prompts y/n for creating a new venv can never be
reached with any combination of CLI options (since always_venv=0 and
never_venv=0 can never happen simultaneously)

This actually makes the --no-virtual-env option pointless, so we may
as well remove it and explicitly set it as the default (it was anyway
previously but by virtue of the never_venv option being undefined)

Change-Id: I3c803533fda55a6814b7536b5c1328312acd3d57
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add support for the coverage extension.

This adds support for the coverage extension and also adds 3
CLI commands to interact with coverage:

nova coverage-start

nova coverage-stop

nova coverage-report

'nova coverage-report' has a required '--filename' argument
which gives the filename for the generated report files.

Change-Id: I9cb002b0e32cfe5572878d2c8436270663c0ae96

Updates keystoneclient so that it uses a print statement to
stderr instead of a logger.warn. This works around problems
caused by the fact that logging isn't always initialized when
this module import runs (and fails) thus causing:

Fixes LP Bug #1090396

Change-Id: I94e2c45eec14edfe3c2f356af6907aa827808a13
'}, {'created': '2012-12-14 21:06:20.000000000', 'message': 'Print to stderr when keyring module is missing.

Updates keystoneclient so that it uses a print statement to
stderr instead of a logger.warn if stderr is a tty.
This works around problems caused by the fact that logging isn't always
initialized when this module import runs (and fails) thus causing:

  No handlers could be found for logger "keystoneclient.client"

instead of the intended log message.

Fixes LP Bug #1090396

Change-Id: I94e2c45eec14edfe3c2f356af6907aa827808a13
'}]
commit_message:
Print to stderr when keyring module is missing.

Updates keystoneclient so that it uses a print statement to
stderr instead of a logger.warn if stderr is a tty.
This works around problems caused by the fact that logging isn't always
initialized when this module import runs (and fails) thus causing:

  No handlers could be found for logger "keystoneclient.client"

instead of the intended log message.

Fixes LP Bug #1090396

Change-Id: I94e2c45eec14edfe3c2f356af6907aa827808a13

commit_message:
Extract periodic task into fork process.

Because periodic_task may run for a long time, especially when have a large
amount of instance. This can delay making response to rpc request. We found
that when running periodic task update_available_resource, nova-compute will
not process the rpc request, until task finished.

Partial descripted in bug #1078811 Bug #1045152

Change-Id: I61c44c04f3c38019be6c98aeb54855e6057e13ec

commit_message:
Make configdrive.py use version.product_string()

Instead of hardcoding 'OpenStack nova' for the publisher
when building ISO images, use version.product_string().
Also append the package version suffix, if any.

Change-Id: If3dfbf895ef7037e15dd3ff8da8f47daecb4d24a
