- http://logs.openstack.org/17875/2/check/gate-nova-pylint/4177 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-12-12 13:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This looks like a good idea in principle, but encouraging the usage of patches seems like a real pain.

If this is made a config option, then it can still have a default value... But Distro/Vendors don't need to patch, just include values in their shipped config.

The same could be said for public cloud providers, they probably want to expose themselves, rather than the pure "Openstack" value or a vendor/distro.

Therefore, a config option would make much more sense in my opinion.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-12-12 17:32:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

+1 to the idea of making these configuration options.

And, to the general idea of being able to set this.. +supercool :)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-12-13 06:57:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Personally, I'd have approved this and made figuring out how to allow it to be overridden a separate thing. It's a reasonable feature to add even without the ability to override.

But yeah, distros will want to override this so it'd be nice to allow it without patching.

One way is config options, but this also makes it easy for *users* to override the values - e.g. if distros put their values in their default nova.conf and users change it for fun, that doesn't seem desirable

Maybe instead you could have a /usr/share/nova/systeminfo.json and a config option to allow users specify a different path? That way it's still user-configurable, but doesn't look so much like something we actually encourage changing."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-13 17:56:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I'm wondering whether this isn't something that needs to be dealt with outside the scope of the libvirt driver.

As an example, the config driver code does

                      '-publisher', ('"OpenStack nova %s"'
                                     % version.version_string()),

to encode the Nova product name + version string in the ISO image. This would probably want to be customizable in the same way as the SMBIOS data.

I don't know whether the user facing REST API has any kind of product identifying information in it, but if there was some kind of "nova version" command, this would also probably want to be keyed into the same data.

So I'm wondering how/where we should put this vendor/product/version information to allow it to be effectively customized by vendors and/or cloud providers where relevant.

Perhaps in the top level 'versions.py' class'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-13 21:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-13 21:27:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Export custom SMBIOS info to QEMU/KVM guests

Provide custom SMBIOS data to QEMU/KVM guests, so that they can
reliably detect the fact that they're running on an OpenStack
platform. Guest OS vendors often need info about the host
virtualization platform to apply the correct billing process
for virtual machines.

Looking at 'dmidecode' in the guest will show something akin
to

  ...snip...
  Handle 0x0100, DMI type 1, 27 bytes
  System Information
        Manufacturer: OpenStack Foundation
        Product Name: OpenStack Nova
        Version: 2013.1-dev
        Serial Number: 35363738-393a-3b3c-3d3e-3f4041424344
        UUID: 2BAFB510-B7DB-4117-A609-452B6E2BD718
        Wake-up Type: Power Switch
        SKU Number: Not Specified
        Family: Not Specified
  ...snip...

Change-Id: I5cdd75cd06ee872e5665f06926951b340ff2f57f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow loading of product/vendor/package info from external file

Currently the version.py file hardcodes some basic info for
the NOVA_PRODUCT, NOVA_VENDOR and NOVA_PACKAGE constants. It
is desirable that OS distro vendors can override/extend this
data in packages they ship. Cloud providers may also desire
to do the same. This allows Nova to optionally load this
data from a /etc/nova/release file. That file should contain
the data in a trivial "ini" format. For example:

  [Nova]
  vendor = Fedora Project
  package = 1.fc18

Note that vendor sare not required to override all strings.
In this example, the 'product' field is not set, leaving
it on the default 'OpenStack Nova' value.

Change-Id: I3d8d32eaf35268c4b0908b0a93b7c9a2ea9c580a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove obsolete VCS version info completely

The VCS version string in nova/version.py has been hardcoded
to 'LOCALBRANCH:LOCALVERSION' since change

  0bbb0e8cb1daa351af91cf97b2bcababfc0c7f9f

The only places which use this info are some logging calls,
and since 'nova-manager version' command. The latter would
more usefully output the distro specific package string.

Delete the VCS related methods in version.py and replace their
usage with a new method version_string_with_package() which
appends the distro-specific package tag

Change-Id: I972b79c329198cb5376d537c6b672830094cd759
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-13 21:00:29.000000000', 'message': 'Define a product & vendor string in version.py

To have one single place where all code in Nova can access
product, vendor & version strings, extend version.py to
expose a product_string(), vendor_string() and package_string()
methods. The product will default to "OpenStack Nova", the
vendor to "OpenStack" and the package to None. The latter is
intended solely for OS distro vendors to include their package
version suffix (eg the "Release:" field from RPM or equiv)

Change-Id: I3eb14d11f8949ce909a8f529851913d3dccf0e8c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2012-12-17 13:12:12.000000000', 'message': 'Define a product, vendor & package strings in version.py

expose a product_string(), vendor_string() and package_string()
methods. The product will default to "OpenStack Nova", the
vendor to "OpenStack" and the package to None. The latter is
intended solely for OS distro vendors to include their package
version suffix (eg the "Release:" field from RPM or perhaps
a VCS tag)

Change-Id: I3eb14d11f8949ce909a8f529851913d3dccf0e8c

commit_message:
Define a product, vendor & package strings in version.py

To have one single place where all code in Nova can access
product, vendor & package strings, extend version.py to
expose a product_string(), vendor_string() and package_string()
methods. The product will default to "OpenStack Nova", the
vendor to "OpenStack" and the package to None. The latter is
intended solely for OS distro vendors to include their package
version suffix (eg the "Release:" field from RPM or perhaps
a VCS tag)

Following changes will make this data configurable via a
plain text file, and then update various parts of Nova to
make use of the data.

Change-Id: I3eb14d11f8949ce909a8f529851913d3dccf0e8c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-12-19 20:39:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm wondering, though, if we should make the argument a positional argument rather than an option, i.e., should the syntax be:

  nova quota-show --tenant=<tenant-id>

or should it be:

  nova quota-show <tenant-id>"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-19 20:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-12-20 10:32:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@vek

Yes, I had a similar thought initially, but decided to stick with the existing syntax to avoid breaking existing scripts that are already using the quota-show verb correctly.

Whereas breaking scripts that are using the bare 'nova quota-show' verb is OK as such scripts were already broken (in the sense of getting incorrect information back from nova-api).

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 10:47:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

as then you'd have an interface that could fail sometimes."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 11:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 11:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-19 20:19:30.000000000', 'message': "Make --tenant a required arg for quota-show

Fixes LP 1088519

Previously, novaclient was incorrectly defaulting to the tenant name
as the tenant ID when retrieving quota thresholds via the os-quota-sets
API extension, in an apparent attempt to default to the current tenant
if no specific tenant is explicitly requested.

As a result, the default quotas were always returned, regardless of
whether there were specific overridden quotas for this tenant.

We now require that the --tenant option is always specified for the
quota-show verb, as a sensible default isn't always possible
(because the tenant ID may be opaque to the client, for example when
the auth token is cached in the keyring from a previous call out to
keystone - now the tenant ID is of course generally embedded in the
nova publicURL retrieved from the service catalog, but that is not
guaranteed to be the case, i.e. I don't think we can safely make
assumptions about that URL format).

This change also makes the quota-show verb more consistent with the
quota-update verb, which currently requires that the tenant is
always explicitly specified.

Change-Id: I1706ad993059e70ca0e2f3bcf7b1d06cbcc39f2d
"}]
commit_message:
Make --tenant a required arg for quota-show

Fixes LP 1088519

Previously, novaclient was incorrectly defaulting to the tenant name
as the tenant ID when retrieving quota thresholds via the os-quota-sets
API extension, in an apparent attempt to default to the current tenant
if no specific tenant is explicitly requested.

As a result, the default quotas were always returned, regardless of
whether there were specific overridden quotas for this tenant.

We now require that the --tenant option is always specified for the
quota-show verb, as a sensible default isn't always possible
(because the tenant ID may be opaque to the client, for example when
the auth token is cached in the keyring from a previous call out to
keystone - now the tenant ID is of course generally embedded in the
nova publicURL retrieved from the service catalog, but that is not
guaranteed to be the case, i.e. I don't think we can safely make
assumptions about that URL format).

This change also makes the quota-show verb more consistent with the
quota-update verb, which currently requires that the tenant is
always explicitly specified.

Change-Id: I1706ad993059e70ca0e2f3bcf7b1d06cbcc39f2d

commit_message:
Avoid logging.getChild for python2.6 compatibility

Tweaking common.config setup_logging to avoid using the getChild()
convenience function means we can run on python 2.6, as getChild was
new in python 2.7

Change-Id: I03698ad09eb16d4f1004512d27b049f22b41c22c
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
update tox.ini to pep8 latest (1.3.4)

Most of the core projects are currently 1.3.3, but since 1.3.4 is
the current latest it seemed best to align with the latest.A
Also add a check to run_tests.sh to ensure peoples local tests align
with the new gate version

fixes bug 1092057

Change-Id: I16dc7e51536781f7a14b7954c24b1aa078b37fa8
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
address uuid overwriting

uuid was being used as a variable and as an import, change
the import so that we don't have a naming collision. Probably
harmless, but bad form.

Change-Id: I99a0a372a62405b309e01d89b516df100b3e278c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-17 08:05:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix image_id in instance resource metadata

Originally the image property in instance resource metadata is correct
since instance information is fetched from db access.

After switching to nova client api, these information is lost
since the returned data format from nova client is different with db
access result.

Image ref and image url is fixed with this patch while kernel_id and
ramdisk_id should be fixed in nova side.

For bug 1090310

Change-Id: I51816b4bd31c09a59e1ef857f8981a45f33f68dc
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix image_id in instance resource metadata

Originally the image property in instance resource metadata is correct
since instance information is fetched from db access.

After switching to nova client api, these information is lost
since the returned data format from nova client is different with db
access result.

Image ref and image url is fixed with this patch while kernel_id and
ramdisk_id should be fixed in nova side.

For bug 1090310

Change-Id: I51816b4bd31c09a59e1ef857f8981a45f33f68dc
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

subject: Centralize the registration of modules.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-17 22:14:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/1/check/gate-keystone-docs/1248 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/1/check/gate-keystone-pep8/2764 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/1/check/gate-keystone-python26/1791 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/1/check/gate-keystone-python27/1792 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/22627 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-12-18 22:31:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm totally lost on why this is necessary? There are no circular dependencies in keystone today and this patch effectively replaces manual injection of driver instances into controllers with the same highly coupled approach that you've been trying to work around for the past few weeks.

Can you post a short diff or something illustrating what's impossible to achieve with the current architecture?"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-12-19 01:34:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It is not a question of highly coupled.  The coupling here is roughly the same.  What is proliferating through the code is the number of places we need to define how to create all of the APIs.  This merely collects them all into a single file.  

What we are going to see with mapping and with trusts is the addition of two new modules that need backends.  I don't want to have to go back and update user_crud and admin_crud to be able to create trusts just so it can create a baseclass controller.  THe logic for creating the Drivers should be encapsulated inside the controller class.  THe only thing I did that was a stretch was to put it into its own file as opposed to emdedding it inside the controller _iinit_ function, but perhaps that is where it belongs."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-12-19 01:51:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-12-19 01:56:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This version drops the APIs in a separate file.  All controllers are initialized in keystone/controller, and minimizes the number of places that would need to be updated in order to add a new controller.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-12-19 02:06:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Note that the Manager object is really just a factory method.  It is not abstracted, but rather hides the details of how to construct the Driver.  Thus, there is no reason to worry about coupling the Managers with their consumers.  By moving the code that calls the constructors for the Drivers  into the controller base class, it minimizes the number of places that need to know that particular detail.  It reduces the amount of cut and paste code.  So it reduces coupling, not increases it.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-19 02:12:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/2/check/gate-keystone-docs/1267 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/2/check/gate-keystone-pep8/2783 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/2/check/gate-keystone-python26/1810 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/2/check/gate-keystone-python27/1811 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/22947 : FAILURE
"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-12-19 02:54:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Centralized initialization, less code, less typing fatigue, less carpal tunnel. Sounds all good to me! :)'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-12-19 13:34:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

(5 inline comments)

This is a regression from basic dependency injection back to hard-coded constructors.

I think a full-on dependency registry would look like overkill for keystone today, BUT if you'd like to create one, it would be **awesome** to have as we add additional backends (e.g. mappings, trusts) and split a few up (identity)."}, {'account_id': 5956, 'date': '2012-12-19 13:36:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Seems sensible to me.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-12-19 14:58:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2012-12-19 15:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I don't know the history of whether this is classed as a "regression" as per Dolph's comments - although from a simplicity point of view this change seems good'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-19 15:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/3/check/gate-keystone-docs/1271 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/3/check/gate-keystone-pep8/2787 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/3/check/gate-keystone-python26/1814 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/3/check/gate-keystone-python27/1815 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18269/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/23001 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-12-19 17:15:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Since I don't think it's fair to block without at least illustrating an alternative approach: https://review.openstack.org/18395"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-12-20 01:39:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Abandoned

I like Dolph's approach better."}]

commit_message:
Sync cinderclient.utils with novaclient.

There are a number of things cleaned up in novaclient.utils that
would be nice to have for cinderclient and also to maintain consistency
in output messages for the shell.

This is probably a prime candidate for OSLO and this change will be
temporary until an OSLO.client_utils can be submitted and merged.

Change-Id: Id667295308e7e313e12007d50eefedbe72167a9f

commit_message:
Added the lockutils, fileutils, gettextutils

The 3par driver, for both iSCSI and Fibre Channel,
that I will commit soon, needs the lockutils to ensure thread safety in
each of the driver entry points.  The driver uses a single shared http
session for all of it's connections to the 3par drive array.
This is required for the driver because of the limitation on the
3par's WSAPI only supporting a very small number of open connections.

For example without this, the driver will have problems when 2 users try and
create a volume at the same time.   I've discovered this in my threaded
stress test tool.

Change-Id: Ic9d7295e7bcbf5c06086ddf5bd9b8b2fe771faa5

commit_message:
Make libvirt driver.listinstances return defined

Currently the Libvirt driver list_instances doesn't return
defined instances. Those instances required during host initialization
for blueprint rebuild-for-ha

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ifb8f703daa4962f4570c53c75c3d66bc5e5132e7
Co-authored-by: Oshrit Feder <oshritf@il.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Add an iptables mangle rule per-bridge for DHCP.

When vhost-net is present on a host, and DHCP services are
run on the same system as guests (multi_host), an iptables
rule is needed to fill packet checksums.  This adds a rule
per-bridge for multi_host networks when vhost-net is present,
similar to how newer versions of libvirt handle the issue for
bridges/networks that it manages.

Fixes LP: #1029430

EDIT: Updated tests and pep8.

Change-Id: I1a51c1d808fa47a77e713dbfe384ffad183d6031

commit_message:
Use one wsgi app, one dbengine worker.

Return to using one wsgi application but use one database engine
per worker process.

Fixes Bug #1089916

Change-Id: Iea4b1b925208317c3c6ee3c9461b6723f3168405

commit_message:
Negative Cinder tests for Volume Types,extra specs

* Adds negative tests for volume types.
* Adds negative tests for volume type extra specs.
* Adds xml client for volume types and extra specs.

Fixes LP Bug #1090229

Change-Id: I97ad07ffff7d85b5901fb4c23b70fe4a8814ebcb

commit_message:
Specify region by name.

Rather than just taking the first region in the array,
specify the name of the region as a string. If the region
is not found, then fallback to the first in the array.

Change-Id: I9f710812cc69a4f4f615ca72483dd58441b3b08a

subject: Clean up soft deletion in sqlaclhemy db api
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2835, 'name': 'Brian Elliott', 'email': 'bdelliott@gmail.com', 'username': 'belliott'}, {'_account_id': 2889, 'name': 'Aeva Black', 'email': 'aeva.online@gmail.com', 'username': 'tenbrae'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 6172, 'name': 'Boris Pavlovic', 'email': 'boris@pavlovic.me', 'username': 'boris-42'}]

[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-12-06 17:28:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-06 17:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/3968 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-06 18:02:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-12-06 18:04:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Sorry, I completely misread how that is to be used. Yes, agree that it's okay as it is.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-12-06 18:09:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-06 18:21:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-12-06 19:38:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-12-06 20:07:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I like the idea of cleaning up the soft delete logic, but I would prefer you didn't do it via monkey patching.  

You can do something like:

 def soft_delete(query):
     return query.query.update({'deleted': True,
             'deleted_at': timeutils.utcnow(),		
             'updated_at': literal_column('updated_at')})"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-06 20:07:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-06 20:29:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Joe Gordon: 
I thought about that way. There is a strong reason why I have chosen to do this with monkey patch.
If you take a look at the work with queries then you will probably see that usually (always) we work with query in this way: 

session.query(model)
 .some_filter1
 .some_filter2
 .some_join
 .some_joine2
 .some_etc
 .and_then_action()

So if we create a new function safe_delete(query) and send it query object, then we will brake the well-established approach.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-06 20:30:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/2/check/gate-nova-merge/13530 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/2/check/gate-nova-docs/9248 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/2/check/gate-nova-pep8/14558 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/2/check/gate-nova-python26/10696 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/2/check/gate-nova-python27/10768 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/21324 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17610/2/check/gate-nova-pylint/3972 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-12-06 21:21:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Yeah, I generally don't like monkey patching 'magic' either, though I see why you did it this way.  I agree with Joe that a slightly uglier usage pattern is preferable to magic."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-12-07 07:48:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It looks like this functionality already exists and we just don't use it often.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py#L62

Example usage:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L298"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-07 08:38:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Brian Elliott: 
Sorry but there is no magic here. We are using basically functionality of python that allows us to add existing method to existing class..

Joe Gordon: 
No functionality doesn't exists... That code works with models, for example: 
session.query(some_model).first() <= here we get instance of NovaBase and we can use delete() method. 

But in this situation:
query = sesssion.query(some_model) <= instance has type of query. 
And there are two possible ways to soft delete: 
for model in query.all(): #array of NovaBase instances
  query.delete() //Thousand of DB requests  
Or
query.update({...}) // 1 request

So we should add our method inside query class to make 1 request instead of thousand."}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-07 08:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

typo: 
for model in query.all(): #array of NovaBase instances
  model.delete() //Thousand of DB requests'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-07 09:16:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I understand that dynamic changing of existing standard classes and methods is not transparent.

But there are several places in code where we are using dynamic substituting of methods, for example here we are wrapping session.query and session.flush:  
def wrap_session(session):
    """Return a session whose exceptions are wrapped."""
    session.query = nova.exception.wrap_db_error(session.query)
    session.flush = nova.exception.wrap_db_error(session.flush)
    return session

And I don't even substitute an existing methods, just add one method to existing class. I don't know why my solution is worse.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-12-07 10:59:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I agree model.delete() doesn't work for multiple rows. 

Using both model.delete() and another soft delete method is confusing.  Not only do they do slightly different things (model.delete doesn't update the updated_at column).  If we are cleaning up soft deletion we should have one way to do soft deletes not two.  And if we keep two they should both be documented.

Instead of monkey patching in a soft_delete command what about something like update(*delete_args,**delete_kwargs)?

And lastly, I prefer a slightly uglier pattern verses using additional monkey matching."}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-07 14:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-07 14:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-07 14:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Joe Gordon: 


I removed unused {'updated_at' : literal_column('updated_at')} from soft_delete. Now both method: delete() in NovaBase and soft_delete() in Query are equal. 

Sorry but I do not completely understand what do you mean:
"Instead of monkey patching in a soft_delete command what about something like update(*delete_args,**delete_kwargs)?" 
Where should be this method? And what should it do?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-07 14:37:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-10 21:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-10 21:17:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

so the purpose of the literal_column in the deletes were so that soft_delete would not modify the updated_at so updated_at would actually contain the last value before it was deleted. Are you asserting that this is not working?"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-10 21:41:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Not exactly. 

If we update with literal_column then we are setting into update_at value that was already stored in update_at. (so update_at is not changed)

And if we remove update_at from update query then we don't change the update_at value at all. (so update_at is not changed also)

So we can safely remove it from update request."}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-10 21:58:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Or there is some hidden functionality ?

In NovaBase for example: 
    updated_at = Column(DateTime, onupdate=timeutils.utcnow)

So if we don't update updated_at it will be automatically seted to utcnow?"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-10 22:22:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-10 22:22:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

correct if we don't set it it gets updated to utcnow."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-10 22:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-10 23:19:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-12-11 08:59:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I would still prefer not to monkey patch sqlalchemy (sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.soft_delete = soft_delete)"}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2012-12-11 15:55:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Joe's point about having only a single means for doing soft deletes, not two, though I don't share his objection to monkey patching. 

I'd probably be ok with either updating the existing model.delete method or the monkey patch, but I lean towards the cleaner syntax and better performance of query.filter(...).soft_delete().

Also, IMNSHO, the existing model.delete() method shouldn't have been called delete at all, since it is not actually deleting anything. I find it confusing to see query.delete and model.delete, but know they behave differently. All the more reason for this patch ;-)"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-12-13 15:42:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Monkey patching"}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2012-12-18 22:16:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (5 inline comments)

some minor inline comments
- clean up the patch in session.py
- remove three changes in api.py'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2012-12-19 22:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

commit_message:
Clean up soft deletion in sqlaclhemy db api

Add soft_delete() method to sqlaclhemy.orm.query.Query
This method is dynamically added to Query class in get_maker() method
of sqlalchemy session module.

In sqlalchemy api change all occurences of:
query.update({
	deleted:True,
	'deleted_at': timeutils.utcnow(),
	'updated_at': literal_column('updated_at')})
to:
query.soft_delete()

Add missing deleted_at column setup for some entries (on soft delete).

Make agent_build_destroy() with 1 db request instead of 2

Make aggregate_host_delete() with 1 db request instead of 2

Make instance_type_access_remove() with 2 db requests instead of 3

Make aggregate_metadata_delete() with 1 db request instead of 2

Make aggregate_delete() with 2 db request instead of 3

blueprint db-api-cleanup

Change-Id: Ib52307e9cc5a45a69259d2495a917de3f5a004e7

commit_message:
Make load_network_driver load passed in driver.

Small fix to the load_network_driver function so that it
loads the driver we pass in as a variable rather than always using
CONF.network_driver.

Change-Id: I9afbbd87bde07ad9d425512dce37b54fd5e3b21e

commit_message:
Split nested stack implementation into abstract and concrete

Split the Stack resource class into an abstract part from which other
resource types inherit and a concrete implementation of the
AWS::CloudFormation::Stack resource type.

Change-Id: Ie7600b94e17ec31b55bae5c4d9501d3f0cbca97c
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Created new volume API Dev Guide.
Included John Griffith edits.

Patchset attempts to remove all files from /target from upload.
Also removes .DS_Store files.
Also removes unrelated WADLs.
Also removes xx - *.xml files.
Also updates pom.xml to use 1.5.2 rather than a SNAPSHOT.

Change-Id: I51341c8707ccb7d4a325cc8b4b5f5a2d95ff1c4a

subject: Adds a launch helper method to wsgi
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-06 20:22:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17628/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-merge/241 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17628/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/56 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17628/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/241 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17628/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/84 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17628/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/241 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17628/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/241 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-12-06 21:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Would definitely like to move to using this for Cinder.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-12-06 23:36:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I likes, I likes even more if included a small test, but I can see how its kinda overkill at this point ;).'}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2012-12-07 01:26:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I was going to, but I wanted to get something up to talk about. I really wasnt sure if this would If its necessary I can make it happen. Next week tho as I'm off tomorrow :D"}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2012-12-07 02:14:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Something else that worries me about the test is that calling launcher.start() is going to pause the unit tests, and im not sure what the value of testing it would be at present... What do u think?'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-12-07 02:51:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I would mock the Service class with a MagicMock, os.common.service as a MagicMock, and pastedeploy.paste_deploy_app to return a Sentinel object and check that the server is called with the Sentinel and that service.launch is called with the MagicMock Service class. But that's a bit overkill for 3 lines and doesn't really test anything except that service.launch is called with our MagicMock, lulz."}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2012-12-07 02:54:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Haha. Nice. If we are striving for 100% that will work. But ya it'll be worthless like u said :D"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-12-07 07:58:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Could you file a blueprint for this? e.g. pastedeploy-wsgi-integration

I had thought pastedeploy was unused by any projects and would go away soon - basically, if you don't need to supply a data object to your WSGI apps the module doesn't do anything interesting right now

I think I'd prefer wsgi.py to not depend on paste at all - it'd be valid to use the module without paste

So, how about adding this helper to the pastedeploy module?

I'd also be up for adding config options which would give defaults for all the launch() parameters

Glance's [paste_deploy] group is a good model for allowing the paste.ini file and app flavor to be configured"}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2012-12-12 00:10:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

I will move this over to paste'}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2012-12-19 21:23:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

wont fix for now. maybe in the future'}]

Hmm, there were some issues with this. I can't get gerrit to let me do them inline, so noting here:
in elements/glance-api/install.d/05-glance-api we have overlap with packaging metadata - Perhaps a XXX note?

And elements/glance-api/first-boot.d/05-glance-api should exist - This shouldn't be first-boot.d, its just a regular file copy - do it during the install phase. first-boot is for things that are machine environment dependent, or nova-metadata dependent."}]

[{'created': '2012-12-19 20:12:47.000000000', 'message': "Fixes the guest image for oslo updates.

* Updates init to install extras (which is not in a apt repo so its pip'd)
* Updates the upstart script to include the guest_info file

fixes bug 1090166

Change-Id: Idbac441e1a5749cbae1b01b2b57ba0c7aaf9b922
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes the guest image for oslo updates.

* Updates init to install extras (which is not in a apt repo so its pip'd)
* Updates the upstart script to include the guest_info file

fixes bug 1090166

Change-Id: Idbac441e1a5749cbae1b01b2b57ba0c7aaf9b922

commit_message:
Update oslo codebase within reddwarf.

* Updated logging,cfg,setup to new oslo
* Split out the paste ini from the conf files
* Modified reddwarf-api/server to use new modules
* Modified reddwarf-manage to use new cfg
* Added rpc helper for rpc services
* Modified reddwarf-taskmanager to use rpc helper
* Modified reddwarf-guestagent to use new rpc helper
* Fixed guestagent api to use rpc proxy
* Fixed taskmanager module to conform to new rpc
* Updated guestagent manager/pkg to use new rpc
* Updated api paste to use keystoneclient auth_token
* Updated managers to use periodic tasks

Implements: blueprint reddwarf/upgrade-oslo

Change-Id: I9ad1b441eca855a4304454014ae746ec51bef8f3

commit_message:
Add expected exception to aggregate_metadata_delete()

This adds a missing client_exceptions() decorator to the conductor's
aggregate_metadata_delete() method, which was missed due to the
timing of when the patches landed. With this, all expected exceptions
in conductor's current set of operations should be properly marked.

Related to bp/no-db-compute-manager

Change-Id: Ifa8cdcb1c7e93aeb95f5dc4fe2e294fe0165cdc5

commit_message:
Move aggregate_get() to conductor

This moves the final remaining aggregate DB operation from the
compute/manager to conductor/manager.

Related to bp/no-db-compute-manager

Change-Id: I1ec6b64d29da21f978f7b72a1f8271fe68e3a44d

This makes building packages which contain the LICENSE file

commit_message:
Convert LICENSE to use unix style line endings.

Ran dos2unix on LICENSE to convert to unit style line endings.
This makes building packages which contain the LICENSE file
a bit nicer... and matches other LICENSE files under the openstack
umbrella which have unix style line endings as well.

Change-Id: Id724d1ba402a590725a2d200f5e0599bce696e5a

commit_message:
Bug 1052674: added support for Swift cache

This patch merely address the Swift cache backward compatibility support.

There's another BP which address the elephant-in-the-room, which is
unified and consistent caching mechanism for all middleware.

See https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/unifed-caching-system-for-middleware

Change-Id: Iab6b4ac61c9aa9e7ad32a394557cb7558bd60a43

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-12-15 15:24:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I wasn't sure about this one as
losetup --find should find a free device atomically.

However there is still the issue of processes
competing for limited loop devices (my kernel
defaults to making 8 available), so retry with
a delay could alleviate this contention.

BTW what year is this? I thought this silly max_loop
limitation was removed years ago...
https://lkml.org/lkml/2007/3/31/126
So it's not set to 8 explicitly on my system
  # cat /sys/module/loop/parameters/max_loop
  0
  # echo 100 > /sys/module/loop/parameters/max_loop 
  -bash: /sys/module/loop/parameters/max_loop: Permission denied
Oh looking at the code I have to explicitly create device nodes, and then the kernel should auto accommodate that.
Quite klunky. So on Fedora/RHEL6 I'd have to do this
to create 256 loop devices: MAKEDEV -v /dev/loop
That would need to be put in rc.local for persistence.

It would be worth mentioning in a comment in the loop
code, that limited loop devices is the reason for retries,
and that increasing the number of available loop devices
will help mitigate the issue (in addition to retrying).

Somewhat related to losetup and retries,
I notice that on some kernels, losetup -d
will intermittently fail, thus leaking a precious
loop device unless the losetup -d is retired:
https://lkml.org/lkml/2012/9/28/62"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-12-15 22:03:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've added a comment about the number of loop devices. I could add a retry for the detach, or execute it more than once. Do you think that's worth it?"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-12-15 22:04:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-15 22:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Make NBD retry logic more generic, add retry to loop.

Other device implementations require retry logic as well. This
change pushes the retry logic up one layer so that its easy to
implement for the other drivers that will benefit from it, and
then adds retry to the loop driver.

This change also adds some unit test coverage for the loop
driver.

Change-Id: Iab0d42d5075e9d50b4e7eb8c7fcef12cae281b40

Fixes Bug #1089168

When a VHD created by Cinder using the iSCSI Target Server is deleted
manually, at the next startup the cinder-volume service terminates with an
exception.
This fix adds a check to verify if the disk exists.

Change-Id: I830cb8332dcef845591bd88cccef1e0e9781ffcc

commit_message:
Fixes a Windows volume driver bug on disk export

Fixes Bug #1089168

When a VHD created by Cinder using the iSCSI Target Server is deleted
manually, at the next startup the cinder-volume service terminates with an
exception.
This fix adds a check to verify if the disk exists.

Change-Id: I830cb8332dcef845591bd88cccef1e0e9781ffcc

commit_message:
Fix WSME arguments handling change

Recent version of WSME makes mandatory to expose arguments. This is just a
simple fix to fix the non-passing tests, but the API will require more work
to be improved and use the new mechanisms.

Change-Id: Icdaa5dc2427383691df07249522799356e70e9d9
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Add option to make exception format errors fatal.

Adds a new fatal_exception_format_errors config option which
defaults to False. This option is use to control how the base
NovaException class handles errors which can occur when it
formats error messages.

The motivation for this change is to be able to enable exception
format checking in our tests by setting
fatal_exception_format_errors=True.

Change-Id: Ie96261ed96bcede4a2b5ec5600cb93c15141a800

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-09-14 22:21:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

This is very cool, but I think we have to wait for grizzly and backport at this point'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-09-17 08:41:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

> in the /proc/<init process of container>/dev/ directory on

This should be /proc/<init process of container>/root/dev/

I know this addresses a feature gap in the LXC driver wrt the OpenStack API, but IMHO we shouldn't be doing this in Nova. This makes too many assumptions about the way the libvirt LXC driver happens to operate today, some of which are definitely going to change in the near future. As a result this code is going to be somewhat fragile to support. So IMHO we should be waiting until the kernel properly supports this type of operation using /proc/$PID/ns/mnt to attach to namespaces, then do it all inside libvirt."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-14 20:17:28.000000000', 'message': 'LXC: Refactor attach and detach of volumes

In essex lxc attach and detach was doing the wrong thing,
it was doing a bind mount of a block device from the host
to the lxc container. This was ineffective and broken at best.

In this refactor, given the PID of the libvirt lxc container
we can find the child process of the lxc container, via the ps command
to find the init process of the lxc container.  Once we have found
the init process.

To find the cgroups path for a given instance the container we traverse
the cgroups filesystem to find where the devices.allow for the lxc
instance and allow the device to be used by the container by giving
the block device major and minor device information.

Once we have the init process we create a device via mknod
in the /proc/<init process of container>/dev/ directory on
the host, After the devices has been attached to the container it
looks and acts like a real block device in the container.

To remove the device from the container we blacklist
the device and remove the device from the container.

Note: In order for the block device to be used by the container
we have to use the "real" block information on the host. Not what
devmapper tells us.

This fixes bug LP: #1009701

Change-Id: Ie3e88e5f9f40770c10e5559f1346c272873f1e8e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
LXC: Refactor attach and detach of volumes

In essex lxc attach and detach was doing the wrong thing,
it was doing a bind mount of a block device from the host
to the lxc container. This was ineffective and broken at best.

In this refactor, given the PID of the libvirt lxc container
we can find the child process of the lxc container, via the ps command
to find the init process of the lxc container.  Once we have found
the init process.

To find the cgroups path for a given instance the container we traverse
the cgroups filesystem to find where the devices.allow for the lxc
instance and allow the device to be used by the container by giving
the block device major and minor device information.

Once we have the init process we create a device via mknod
in the /proc/<init process of container>/dev/ directory on
the host, After the devices has been attached to the container it
looks and acts like a real block device in the container.

To remove the device from the container we blacklist
the device and remove the device from the container.

Note: In order for the block device to be used by the container
we have to use the "real" block information on the host. Not what
devmapper tells us.

This fixes bug LP: #1009701

Change-Id: Ie3e88e5f9f40770c10e5559f1346c272873f1e8e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

Import cfg module in extract_opts.py.

Updates the tools/conf/extract_opts.py module so it
imports cfg again.

Fixes "global name 'cfg' is not defined" errors which occur
without it.

This files comes from oslo, so needs to be submitted there first, and it can then be synced back to nova."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2012-12-12 13:57:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

agree, needs to be in oslo first. also, this seems to be a new hard dependency. is there a way to make it optional please?"}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-12-12 15:07:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I'll see about getting in the changes to oslo.

Davanum, are you talking about making the build dependency on keyring optional, because the actual usage of this *is* already optional. If you don't specify 'secure_source' in nova.conf then everything behaves exactly as it does today, even if a config key has been defined as 'secure'."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2012-12-12 15:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Yes, build time dependency'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-12-12 16:11:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Okay, I'll see what I can do. Thanks for the feedback!"}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-12-12 17:02:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Just out of curiosity, why does it matter that there's a new dependency?"}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2012-12-12 17:25:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Ken,

From what i have seen and heard, one should post to the dev mailing list, get consensus before adding a new dependency.

thanks,
dims'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-12-12 18:05:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

it's important for the various Linux distributors that are substantial contributors to have some say on whether dependencies are sane and something they can support.

Also, the commit comment shouldn't include the blueprint url. Use

blueprint pw-keyrings

and the ci system will build the link correctly."}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-12-12 20:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Im ok with the extra dependendency but the openstack/common stuff should be addressed somewhere else shouldnt it?'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-12-12 20:31:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I think this was meant as a prototype, to eventually move into openstack common. Seems like that time has come.

Can we also clean up the review commit message (or just move this commit to openstack-common do that also). Seems like its pretty scattered? Since its just 1 commit it doesn't seem so useful to have "updated dependency based on review comments" since there wasn't any other commit to base that on (ie 1 commit can't have updates) ;-)'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-12-13 23:12:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

From the discussion on the mailing list, it sounds like keyring is already in the repos and therefore can be a hard dependency. 

So... unless anybody objects, when I move this over into oslo, I'll keep the same basic logic that's here.

Thanks for all the input!"}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-12-19 15:04:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

This has been redone in oslo. Please see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18357/1
 for details.'}]

commit_message:
Use keyring to keep passwords secure

This is an implementation to use (optionally) use keyring for
passwords so that they don't need to be in clear text in the
config files. See the blueprint
(https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/pw-keyrings) for
usage details.

Added changes from review.

Resubmit just to see if the build dependency error was transient.

Updated dependency based on review comments

Fixed (more) pep8 issues

blueprint pw-keyrings

Change-Id: Ib352e72a5d550ce61ad85f2ffd06d9ce41c249a6

Hi,
 
some more comments from me.
there are a couple of things I would like to bring to the mailing list, such as binding members to quantum ports, and the use of the operational status for a resource. 

Before we merge this patch, I would like to know if we want to do API unit tests using the LBaaS plugin class (as we do for other extensions and core APIs). These tests will verify that routes are correctly mapped, and that validators work correctly.

I also think we can start fixing now how members are handled in the pool, as it seems we've agreed for a solution on the mailing list."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-12-19 12:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (6 inline comments)

commit_message:
The patch introduces an API extension for LBaaS service

- API extension
- abstract base class for plugin
- some new validators were added to quantum/api/v2/attributes.py

Implements: blueprint lbaas-restapi-tenant
Change-Id: Ic2fd4debc4969389b395ce7352ab208c6854018b

There are some environment variables that are derived in stack.sh
and cubersome to re-create later, so save them at the end of stack.sh
for use by other supporting scripts, such as openrc.

Change-Id: I1bbf717b970f8ceac0ff7da74aeaf19474997e07

commit_message:
Write selected env variables to .stackenv

There are some environment variables that are derived in stack.sh
and cubersome to re-create later, so save them at the end of stack.sh
for use by other supporting scripts, such as openrc.

Change-Id: I1bbf717b970f8ceac0ff7da74aeaf19474997e07

This patch checks if n-net is enabled rather than any nova service
before creating networks through nova. Fixes bug 1073313

Change-Id: I8810737ddbb26a5e281060f5395cfad5d186b6d3
'}]
commit_message:
nova-manage network commands only when n-net enabled

This patch checks if n-net is enabled rather than any nova service
before creating networks through nova. Fixes bug 1073313

Change-Id: I8810737ddbb26a5e281060f5395cfad5d186b6d3

Update the apt-get command to build mysql dependency for ubuntu.
It currenly says apt-get install build-dep python-mysqldb
which should just be apt-get build-dep python-mysqldb

Change-Id: I541f7b80802a6b7191f2fe0338965ef425e7c2fd
'}]
commit_message:
Update command on devref doc

Update the apt-get command to build mysql dependency for ubuntu.
It currenly says apt-get install build-dep python-mysqldb
which should just be apt-get build-dep python-mysqldb

Change-Id: I541f7b80802a6b7191f2fe0338965ef425e7c2fd

commit_message:
Fixed deleting instance booted from invalid vol

1. Translated the exception (NotFound) raised from Cinder client to
Nova's native exception (VolumeNotFound).
2. Added unit test coverage.

Fixes LP: #1087214.

Change-Id: I3cee31a9fd068b65a4097f3f3054aebb69d9ba61

commit_message:
Fix a crash when launching qcow2 images containing snapshots

Break out of the loop when we encounter 'Snapshot list:'
in the output from `qemu-img info` instead of failing
to parse and crashing.

Fixes bug: 1070088
Change-Id: I5f501c599b94e0ac13892c97d60ec740ac7e641d
cherry-picked: b4b897e7acebea1ccff336a5fad9313fd3f51326

[{'created': '2012-12-17 16:27:44.000000000', 'message': "xenapi: Enhance devstack progress monitoring

Fixes bug 1091299

XenServer - devstack install monitors a log file to see, if the devstack
installation is finished. This log file does not contain all the
information to properly detect the state of the devstack installation.
With this change, the devstack's log file is monitored instead of the
bootscript's.

Change-Id: I8dd24c4fe04e4cba67704d374a8eb7a90741d0c8
"}]
commit_message:
xenapi: Enhance devstack progress monitoring

Fixes bug 1091299

XenServer - devstack install monitors a log file to see, if the devstack
installation is finished. This log file does not contain all the
information to properly detect the state of the devstack installation.
With this change, the devstack's log file is monitored instead of the
bootscript's.

Change-Id: I8dd24c4fe04e4cba67704d374a8eb7a90741d0c8

'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2012-12-14 17:09:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good, but ref rewriting GettingStarted.rst, we need to keep in mind the following:
- It's used to generate a script which runs the integration tests, we don't want to break this
- We point directly to it from the wiki as the most up-to-date source of install documentation, will we still be able to do this after the rewrite/restructure?
- I'm trying to converge the scripts so we can have identical (or very similar) install procedure for both Fedora and Ubuntu/Debian - it would be good if we can figure out a way to have a single getting started guide (maybe rendered in a few flavors with a few variable tweaked) - I was looking to do this via restructured text variables and include directives, but the latter are disabled on github so we should try to figure out a good way to do this and minimise duplication/maintenance-overhead"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2012-12-14 18:47:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'll update as many URLs as I can to point to the new location once this is approved. Even though GettingStarted.rst is now part of a bigger developer guide I think we can still link to it directly and use it as an integration test.

How about we have a GettingStarted.rst with both fedora and ubuntu/debian commands, and use some kind of markup to denote which the commands belong to. Maybe we could create our own substitution directives:
http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/user/rst/quickref.html#substitution-references-and-definitions

Then the integration script can filter by the markup that precedes the executable code."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2012-12-17 20:23:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Awesome, thanks for taking this on Steve.

re GettingStarted, I think in the long term that has to disappear. There are only two sensible ways to install heat: using devstack for development, or with RPM/deb packages for users. Obviously we have to improve the packaging before we can deprecate it, but that has to be the goal.

Here's my suggestion: leave api.md and GettingStarted.rst where they are for now so that no links get broken, and work toward replacing them with WADLs and new, package-focussed user guides respectively. When those are complete, we can remove the old ones (or replace with a simple link to the new ones).

I think it would be helpful if the new package-based getting started guide was also executable. I doubt we'll want to be doing anything fancy with includes (have you seen the conversion script?!! https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/tools/rst2script.sed), but we can certainly factor out all the non-visible code into separate shell scripts with functions we can call from multiple places.

(BTW doc/docbkx/api-ref/pom.xml looks like it needs to be scrubbed of its Keystone references still.)"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2012-12-17 20:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-17 20:27:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
A new documention structure, ready for contributions

Here are some skeletons for the documentation which will need to be written.

doc/source
	A Sphinx based document which will be aimed at heat developers.
    	This also contains .rst files which generate the man files
doc/docbkx/api-ref
	Docbook and WADL for the REST API, with the intent of moving this
	to api-site to publish to api.openstack.org
doc/docbkx/heat-admin
	Docbook manual targeted at Heat admins, with the intent of moving this
        to openstack-manuals to publish to docs.openstack.org
doc/docbkx/heat-cli
	Docbook manual targeted at users of the Heat CLI, with the intent of
	moving this to openstack-manuals to publish to docs.openstack.org

Dude, wheres my man pages?
docs/man
	is deleted, now generated into doc/build/man

Packaging will need to be updated to generate the man pages

commit_message:
Add image metadata API extension

This patch introduces an API extension that will expose the volume
metadata inherited from the image if the volume was created from an image.

This data will be used by Nova when booting from volume without any
image supplied.

In addition, the patch introduces a helper method on the volume.API
class for accessing the image metadata and also updates the policy.json
files to be aware of the new extension.

This patch is part of the blueprint improve-boot-from-volume

This patch also introduces DocImpact as it extends the cinder API

Change-Id: I64515cc02f8de863e65e96c66eb1fda1a1954ac7

This is useless and causes problem with library using glanceclient. Glance
has already a workaround for this, see:

    https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/master/glanceclient/shell.py#L294

But this doesn't even fix the basic usage of the glanceclient API, so let's
start by fixing the documentation to stop spreading mistakes.

Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
"}]
commit_message:
Do not include version in Glance API

This is useless and causes problem with library using glanceclient. Glance
has already a workaround for this, see:

    https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/master/glanceclient/shell.py#L294

But this doesn't even fix the basic usage of the glanceclient API, so let's
start by fixing the documentation to stop spreading mistakes.

Change-Id: I80aa84d48de5d62954db1fb72fac64b5d9dfcfed
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Fix API samples generation.

In Change: Ie46b24a65145c407d46974b63a97a84911223547 a check
was added to _verify_response() to verify the samples.

However, when trying to generate new samples this blocks
_write_sample() because it attempts to read a non-existent file.

This change ensures that the sample is created before the
verification and still retains the behavior that the samples are
only updated on changes.

Change-Id: I1527ba71676b2e1e10bd334f2a7878404d12600c

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-12-18 16:47:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I actually think --parallel is a good default, as it goes faster. I'd be happy with a new option on run_tests not to do that though."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-12-18 16:51:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sean: it goes faster at the sacrifice of *everything* else!

On a similar note I think it is worth mentioning that 'make -j N' will speed up your builds on Linux too... but it isn't the default. Perhaps I just got used to this... but this has always made sense to me.

At the very least we need to not hard code it."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-12-18 16:53:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sean: Also, I'd like to avoid adding new *top level* options to run_tests.sh if possible. Given we already use -* as $testerops anyway allowing --parallel to get passed in made most sense to me."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-12-18 16:55:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Goal here: safe defaults... but allow for optimization.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-12-18 18:40:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with Sean'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-12-19 01:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Still not the biggest fan of this as a default.. but I suppose I can (just as easily) add --concurrency=1 to tame the parallel option.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-12-19 01:02:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Using --concurrency=1 for now.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-18 16:17:52.000000000', 'message': "run_tests.sh: disable --parallel by default.

Having the ability to do parallel testing is great... but having
it on by default doesn't make sense. If you run tests on your
local workstation/laptop parallel testing *kills* performance
for other tasks. Given that most of us run tests locally first
(or should) it makes sense to disable it by default.

Users and CI system can easily add back --parallel via the testropts
if they choose to do so.

Change-Id: I6b3234c1f64f0b99c54a4b0e471141eae9972fe6
"}]
commit_message:
run_tests.sh: disable --parallel by default.

Having the ability to do parallel testing is great... but having
it on by default doesn't make sense. If you run tests on your
local workstation/laptop parallel testing *kills* performance
for other tasks. Given that most of us run tests locally first
(or should) it makes sense to disable it by default.

Users and CI system can easily add back --parallel via the testropts
if they choose to do so.

Change-Id: I6b3234c1f64f0b99c54a4b0e471141eae9972fe6

commit_message:
Use requests module for HTTP/HTTPS

* Implement correct certificate verification
* Add --os-cacert
* Rework tests for requests

Pinned requests module to < 1.0 as 1.0.2 is now current in pipi
as of 17Dec2012.

Blueprint: tls-verify

Change-Id: I71066ff7297f3b70c08b7ae1c8ae8b6a1b82bbae

commit_message:
Add use of TimeOverride fixture

This moves the TimeOverride fixture into nova/test.py.

Replaces cases of set_time_override paired with clear_time_override
in tearDown() in tests with use of the TimeOverride fixture

Fixes the problem with test_quota.py where there were missing
clear_time_override calls by using the TimeOverride fixture instead

Change-Id: I438b767421a167de42441a2366373a25762297ff

commit_message:
Adds matching clear_time_override calls

Adds matching clear_time_override to tearDown functions
for tests which call set_time_override. The lack of clear_time_override
was causing failures in other testcases.

Change-Id: I66de95a791123702abfd5bc697c3b81739ab7ab3

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-18 09:30:19.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor Ring::get_nodes() and Ring::get_part_nodes()

Add a _get_part_nodes() method in Ring class, then call it in Ring::get_nodes() and Ring::get_part_nodes().

In order to reduce duplicate codes.

Change-Id: Id92f8dfd08388305638a2ba2ab64e77545c14cba
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor Ring::get_nodes() and Ring::get_part_nodes()

Add a _get_part_nodes() method in Ring class, then call it in Ring::get_nodes() and Ring::get_part_nodes().

In order to reduce duplicate codes.

Change-Id: Id92f8dfd08388305638a2ba2ab64e77545c14cba

commit_message:
Move network_driver into new nova.network.driver

Add a new load_network_driver() function which constrains the use of the
network_driver option and move the option into nova.network.driver.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I0a839765890093dc871b48435cfd113e0f8e46c4

commit_message:
network/api add_fixed_ip correctly passes uuid

network/api.py add_fixed_ip_to_instance() was passing the
instance id instead of the uuid.

fixes bug 1091598

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-17 16:06:50.000000000', 'message': 'Log error on failure to load paste deploy app.

Fixes bug 1091294

Avoids possible silent failure of service launch when say a
dependency such as keystone is missing (but required by the
configured paste_deploy flavor).

Change-Id: I9a63d24bcf0a93277829d24073268210d2c063d3
'}]
commit_message:
Log error on failure to load paste deploy app.

Fixes bug 1091294

Avoids possible silent failure of service launch when say a
dependency such as keystone is missing (but required by the
configured paste_deploy flavor).

Change-Id: I9a63d24bcf0a93277829d24073268210d2c063d3

commit_message:
Move DNS manager options into network.manager

The instance_dns_manager, instance_dns_domain and
floating_ip_dns_manager options are only used in nova.network.manager.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: Ic4dfe01ec87e0b9a4ba244f85cf0a81568f3f9bf

commit_message:
Traceback when user doesn't have permission.

When a user tries to access an image that is
forbidden it sends an HTTPForbidden. Inform the user
with a help message that the permission is not available
to them.

Change-Id: I3082c789876440226b5f177216ec628436c7b3ce
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Makes UnprocessableEntity message more relevant

There are three disparate reasons a _validate_can_perform_action call
can fail; the returned error message now reports the offending status
as it applies, instead of the blanket self.status.

Change-Id: I04c668657675f41d097575502b6ada3516fb3ccb
Fixes: bug #1086540

heat.common.crypt

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I8753524324fb9a20c30b41a114b265b336b3d54c
'}, {'created': '2012-12-17 20:47:43.000000000', 'message': 'Properly remove the time override in quota tests.

Using set_time_override directly makes it easy to forget to call
clear_time_override, and forgetting to call it will break tests
that rely on time being sensible, advancing normally etc. Using
useFixture(TimeOverride()) ensures that clear_time_override is
automatically called when the test ends.

Change-Id: I8753524324fb9a20c30b41a114b265b336b3d54c
'}, {'created': '2012-12-17 21:50:17.000000000', 'message': 'Properly remove the time override in quota tests.

Using set_time_override directly makes it easy to forget to call
clear_time_override, and forgetting to call it will break tests
that rely on time being sensible, advancing normally etc. Using
useFixture(TimeOverride()) ensures that clear_time_override is
automatically called when the test ends.

Change-Id: I8753524324fb9a20c30b41a114b265b336b3d54c
'}]
commit_message:
Properly remove the time override in quota tests.

Using set_time_override directly makes it easy to forget to call
clear_time_override, and forgetting to call it will break tests
that rely on time being sensible, advancing normally etc. Using
useFixture(TimeOverride()) ensures that clear_time_override is
automatically called when the test ends.

Change-Id: I8753524324fb9a20c30b41a114b265b336b3d54c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-17 18:22:20.000000000', 'message': 'Added conf support for security groups

Modified the way nova.compute.api.API loads the security group API.
Previously it would accept a named-parameter and if that was None, default
to SecurityGroupAPI. It still accepts a named-parameter but if that is
None, then it will attempt to load the API from CONF, and then default
to SecurityGroupAPI. The basic use-case should not be altered by these
changes.

Implements: blueprint nova-securitygroups-expansion
Change-Id: Ib252a0755f320289c3c7cb6518d55e63d3392789
'}]
commit_message:
Added conf support for security groups

Modified the way nova.compute.api.API loads the security group API.
Previously it would accept a named-parameter and if that was None, default
to SecurityGroupAPI. It still accepts a named-parameter but if that is
None, then it will attempt to load the API from CONF, and then default
to SecurityGroupAPI. The basic use-case should not be altered by these
changes.

Implements: blueprint nova-securitygroups-expansion
Change-Id: Ib252a0755f320289c3c7cb6518d55e63d3392789

- http://logs.openstack.org/17456/2/check/gate-swift-python27/1255 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17456/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/20993 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:36:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Almost 400 lines of code to populate install_requires?  Also I kind of like the == on deps, if the dependency is a version we've tested and know to work."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:57:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

* Adding openstack.common is the proper to way to use it for now, AFAIK, and is required by OpenStack policy;
* Using == disallows using operating system packages, which was a requirement for this patch, as I have been instructed.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-12-04 22:24:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Then it's a stupid policy.  Crapping half of openstack-common into our code base isn't necessary.  You could pull tools/pip-requires into a list with like two lines of code.  Or just make it a static list, there's only 7 entries now and it hardly ever changes.

The >= thing just scares me because of all the games we had to play with webob, where every new release changed the API in new and exciting ways."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-04 23:47:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I would like to avoid becoming part of the copypastecode party if we can. There should be a python-openstack-setuptools package with this stuff in it or something.

As far as the == versus >= thing, I'd be fine with a known-tested version range. The current range is just a single version because those are the versions we at Rackspace use in production. If we test other versions of dependencies and are convinced they're compatible, we should add them to the range. We can't know we work with future versions since they don't exist and we don't control how those dependencies will support backward compatibility. For instance, if pastedeploy 2.x is released, it might not support the 1.3.3 contract."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-12-05 21:30:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

AFAIK oslo (openstack-common) is meant to be released someday somehow, but I'm not the person you want to talk to about this.

About >= I agree, but the fact is we can't know in advance when it'll break, so the common thing done is to use >= and add a <= when something that breaks is released."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-12-05 23:38:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I also don't think it's worth adding a dependency on oslo just to avoid manually updating the list of dependencies or writing a one-liner to generate it automatically ourselves.

Maybe later oslo will give us something worth the cost of adding more dependencies."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-12-11 10:14:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-11 11:01:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-12-11 13:39:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-11 14:05:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-12-11 14:36:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Greg this change is useful for other project that want to integrate with swift.

You guys rackspace public cloud are using packages? do you generate the debian package requirement on what available in pip-requires ?'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2012-12-11 16:50:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

This seems alright with me (with one really minor nit).  I tried it out and it didn't try to install pypi packages over my already installed os packages which was the main reason we had pulled the requires stuff out a long time ago.  I'm only +1 it for the moment because I want to hear other's weigh in."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-11 17:54:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I don't agree with >= but that's just my opinion of course.
I prefer known tested versions.
If a new version of something comes out and we'd like to allow it, we should test it and add it to the requires range, in my opinion.
Main reason for this is so that apt-get upgrades don't accidentally bust someone's installation, for instance. If folks generally are okay with this risk, I'll just shut up about it. :)"}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2012-12-11 18:49:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Yeah I was looking at the >= packages.  I'm a lot less concerned now that we don't have webob.  I looked through all the packages and they appear to be pretty stable.  The only one I would be somewhat concerned about is pastedeploy.  All of that said, I'm also running on the latest LTS which has much more recent packages of most of them, and they seem to be working fine.  I would be fine with going with >= until an issue with a specific version is found and cap it at that point."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-12-12 09:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think there is some consensus as said by chuck that if we are seeing problems with the >= and versions non tested, we would back this off.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-12-12 10:18:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-12 10:52:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build successful
