'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-12-12 11:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-12 14:32:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Just reiterating my dislike of the "allow it to break someday and fix it then" policy. Otherwise, I'm fine with this change.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2012-12-12 19:31:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Chmouel: I don't think there is really consensus for using >= yet, was just offering some thoughts for discussion.  It seems that, for now, most are against it, so it might be best if we just leave it at == for now

Julien:  If we go with ==, I think it will be easy to get in

--
Chuck"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-12 19:37:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Heheh, I don't know that most are against it either. So far, there's the submitter (for, presumably), Chmouel (for), you (for), and then me (against). ;) If other folks care, they should probably comment."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-12 19:39:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Oh, I forgot Michael (against). So we have 3-2 with the == winning!'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-12 19:41:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Sorry, with >= winning. Nevermind, I'll shut up now. :)"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-12-12 23:07:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Just to emphasis: be aware that using == is going to make "setup.py develop" a PITA for developers since it's going to install THIS precise version of Python packages. And this is something notmyname explicitly told me to avoid, therefore the >=.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-12-13 03:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Actually it's going to do that anyway, since setuptools can't recognize the version numbers of installed deb packages.  Which is pretty annoying.  I don't really know how to reconcile the two goals.

Also, doing a "setup.py install" will now pull in argparse and python-keystoneclient and httplib2 and prettytable.  :(  I think we should move python-swiftclient to test-requires.  And kick whoever made python-swiftclient depend on python-keystoneclient.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-12-13 03:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

Oh I may be slightly wrong there, all the python-keystoneclient stuff may only get pulled in when you're doing a "setup.py develop", not an install.  Which isn't quite so bad.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-12-13 20:19:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Seems reasonable to me (including the >=).  This shouldn't affect packagers much (like us, RAX, Canonical, RedHat, etc), since package dependencies should handle everything that Swift package needs... and be tested together, etc.  Likewise, it shouldn't hurt deployers, who are probably all using packages (debs, RPMs, etc.) to manage dependencies.

I just ran "sudo python ./setup.py develop" in my SAIO without python-swiftclient around, and it pulled in python-swiftclient-1.2.0.tar.gz from PyPi and it doesn't look like any keystone stuff was pulled in.

I admit, I don't know much about the cases where having install_requires filled in actually helps something (hence just a +1), but I think it at least won't hurt anything I care about :).'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-12-17 15:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

FYI this is blocking https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18231/'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-12-17 20:36:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I don't generally disagree with gholt, but when I do - it's over unimportant stuff.

setuptools seems to be doing the right thing with version numbers even WRT system installed packages.  I don't think it used to be that smart?  Anyway, I'm totally cool changing setup.py - yay!

RE: the >= vs. ==

We should either use >= and trust that most of our depends are fairly stable.  swob FTW.  Or be real vigilant about updating the == version to match the more current stable releases (e.g. xattr==0.6.2).  Since we haven't been doing that, and >= seems like less work in general...

I think this should merge as is."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-12-17 22:57:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Could not resist : http://cdn.memegenerator.net/instances/400x/32056120.jpg'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-12-18 11:34:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

so it seems that we have 2 +2 and 1 +1 in favor and only one -1 from gholt. anyone strongly against if I click on the approve button?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-18 18:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://zuul.openstack.org/'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-12-18 18:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

It does seem that (in my testing my my SAIO, YMMV) setuptools does respect the system package versions.

I prefer >= for dependencies over == until we see a new version of a dependency that breaks (as webob was wont to do).'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-18 18:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-18 18:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build successful

'}]

[{'created': '2012-12-04 11:50:47.000000000', 'message': "Use install_requires in setup.py

Using install_requires makes sure that if some code is using Swift internal
and wants to require Swift, all its dependencies have been already pulled.
This is really useful on test automation for example, otherwise, code might
be failing because on of the module listed in pip-requires is not instaled.

This patch uses openstack.common easyness to build the list. Also, we change
the pip-requires files to use >= rather than ==, so the requirements are
easily fulfiled with distribution provided packages. I don't think there's
any real reason to use ==.

commit_message:
Use install_requires in setup.py

Using install_requires makes sure that if some code is using Swift internal
and wants to require Swift, all its dependencies have been already pulled.
This is really useful on test automation for example, otherwise, code might
be failing because on of the module listed in pip-requires is not instaled.

Also, we change the pip-requires files to use >= rather than ==, so the
requirements are easily fulfiled with distribution provided packages.

Change-Id: I65814bcd8ce798da21a5c17b4d5916a23f59e962
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Use service fixture in DB servicegroup tests.

It was possible that the services created by the DB servicegroup tests
hung around and conflicted with other tests. Move the services used by
these tests into a fixture so that they can be cleaned up properly.

To ensure cleanup happens call Service.kill() on the service.

Change-Id: I38aafc6b6d3a17f104db9d8f13b1ab3b4632d470

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-18 03:17:03.000000000', 'message': 'Reset the IPv6 API backend when resetting the conf stack.

This fixes test isolation errors where tests were running with
the wrong ipv6 backend and failing. The failures occured because
Python discovers tests in filesystem order rather than a sorted
order, and the test that was changing the backen had previously
always run later under nose, which does not use filesystem order.

Change-Id: Ife4370d0747b269c9bc9aabb50c531cb6c9fec13
'}, {'created': '2012-12-18 03:19:11.000000000', 'message': 'Reset the IPv6 API backend when resetting the conf stack.

the wrong ipv6 backend and failing. The failures occured because
Python discovers tests in filesystem order rather than a sorted
order, and the test that was changing the backend had previously
always run later under nose, which does not use filesystem order.

Change-Id: Ife4370d0747b269c9bc9aabb50c531cb6c9fec13

'}]
commit_message:
Reset the IPv6 API backend when resetting the conf stack.

This fixes test isolation errors where tests were running with
the wrong ipv6 backend and failing. The failures occured because
Python discovers tests in filesystem order rather than a sorted
order, and the test that was changing the backend had previously
always run later under nose, which does not use filesystem order.

Change-Id: Ife4370d0747b269c9bc9aabb50c531cb6c9fec13

commit_message:
Split endpoint records in SQL by interface

This migrates the SQL backend such that v2 endpoints containing up to 3
URL's (public, internal and admin) stored in 'extra' are split into
unique endpoints.

Because legacy "endpoints" (each having publicUrl, internalUrl and
adminUrl) are no longer conceptually identical to v3's "endpoints" (each
having an interface and a url), new ID's are assigned to each entity and
each API continues to operate using with independent sets of endpoint
ID's.

Endpoints created on the v3 API are not exposed on the v2 API.

Change-Id: I2ba59d55907313ae65e908585fc49be0c4ce899a

'}, {'created': '2012-12-05 15:34:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add DBDuplicateEntry exception for unique constraint violations

Unique constraint violation is wrapped by IntegrityError in SqlAlchemy.
SqlAlchemy doesn't unify errors from different DBs so we must do this in nova.
Also in some tables (for example instance_types) there are more than one unique
constraint. This means we should get names of columns, which values violate
unique constraint, from error message.

Unique constraint violations messages are different for different DB backedns:

1) sqlite:
    1 column - (IntegrityError) column c1 is not unique
    N columns - (IntegrityError) column c1, c2, ..., N are not unique

2) postgres:
    1 column - (IntegrityError) duplicate key value violates unique
                   constraint "users_c1_key"
    N columns - (IntegrityError) duplicate key value violates unique
                   constraint "name_of_our_constraint"

3) mysql:
    1 column - (IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry 'value_of_c1' for key
                   'c1'")
    N columns - (IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry 'values joined
                   with -' for key 'name_of_our_constraint'")

There is no information about table and columns in `N columns` messages for
mysql and postgres. So we should make name convention for UniqueConstraints
name: "uniqcons__c1_x_c2_x_c3" means that columns c1, c2, c3 are in
UniqueConstraint.
Also there is another way to get columns name from unique constraint:
    1) Get table name.
    2) Load table = Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True).
    3) Find unique constraint that is in table.constraints by name.
    4) Get columns names from unique constraint object.
But I think that it is a bad approach because:
    1) We must do table autoload in exception handling
    2) There is no easy way to get table name in wrap_db_error() method.

Remove Duplicate exception handling from models.save() method.

Add new DBDuplicateEntry exception to exceptions module.

Add handling for Integrity Error in exeption wrapper.

blueprint db-unique-keys

commit_message:
Add DBDuplicateEntry exception for unique constraint violations

Unique constraint violation is wrapped by IntegrityError in SqlAlchemy.
SqlAlchemy doesn't unify errors from different DBs so we must do this in nova.
Also in some tables (for example instance_types) there are more than one unique
constraint. This means we should get names of columns, which values violate
unique constraint, from error message.

Unique constraint violations messages are different for different DB backedns:

1) sqlite:
    1 column - (IntegrityError) column c1 is not unique
    N columns - (IntegrityError) column c1, c2, ..., N are not unique

2) postgres:
    1 column - (IntegrityError) duplicate key value violates unique
                   constraint "users_c1_key"
    N columns - (IntegrityError) duplicate key value violates unique
                   constraint "name_of_our_constraint"

3) mysql:
    1 column - (IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry 'value_of_c1' for key
                   'c1'")
    N columns - (IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry 'values joined
                   with -' for key 'name_of_our_constraint'")

There is no information about table and columns in `N columns` messages for
mysql and postgres. So we should make name convention for UniqueConstraints
name: "uniq_c1_x_c2_x_c3" means that columns c1, c2, c3 are in
UniqueConstraint.
Also there is another way to get columns name from unique constraint:
    1) Get table name.
    2) Load table = Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True).
    3) Find unique constraint that is in table.constraints by name.
    4) Get columns names from unique constraint object.
But I think that it is a bad approach because:
    1) We must do table autoload in exception handling
    2) There is no easy way to get table name in wrap_db_error() method.

Remove Duplicate exception handling from models.save() method.

Add new DBDuplicateEntry exception to exceptions module.

Add new wrapper in sqlalchemy get_session() for handling Integrity Error.

blueprint db-unique-keys

Change-Id: Ic8fd8e0613f10d06c1d7d90f76a436099e8bfef2

commit_message:
Support non-default role_id_attribute

As is, a default value of 'cn' is hardcoded as the attribute name (which
also happens to be the default value in keystone.config) used for role
grants, revokes, etc.

Change-Id: Ic36e6d726e2dc48714703c2dd7a433f3d34b78b1

commit_message:
Allow the lvm backed drivers to use mirrrors

Adds a new configuration option called lvm_mirrors. If this is
set to a value > 0, it will create the specified number of mirrors
when creating volumes. Note that lvm_mirrors + 2 pvs are required
in the volume group for lvm mirroring to work properly.

Change-Id: I7e28d11c48cdbb99e17b0930b720fbd805bf9931

commit_message:
Modify the v2 image controller to use domain model

This change brings in the domain model and uses it in the images
controller with a mind to cleaning up the controller as much as
possible. The controller test changes are focused on different fixture
setup and assertion format, rather than changes in behavior.

Part of implementing bp:glance-domain-logic-layer

Change-Id: I9c5858cb5a5ad01caf5d8283b5342e3098ac96ac

The code in this directory is the v1 to integrate quantum with nova. at
that time, quantum hasn't a client and keystone support. At the nova side

commit_message:
Remove the deprecated quantum v1 code and directory.

The code in this directory is the v1 to integrate quantum with nova. at
that time, quantum hasn't a client and keystone support. At the nova side
, there is a quantum manager that connect to quantum server. now, all code
has been removed execept the nova_ipam_lib which is unused too. this patch
removes the nova_ipam_lib.py.

Change-Id: I05146d47fb57f215f8d010dbde8fdc0b2de55301

[{'created': '2012-12-14 16:31:18.000000000', 'message': "Fix use of venv in Tempest.

Currently when running Tempest tests with run_tests.sh a venv
isn't being used. This leaves tempest at the mercy of whatever
required package versions are installed on the system.

This patch takes install_venv.py and with_venv.sh from nova and
integrates them into run_tests to ensure that the correct
dependencies versions from pip-requires and test-requires are
being used.

Change-Id: I4bf4a02890a33c4034e4493d1763ed4019fdf46e
"}, {'created': '2012-12-18 14:52:31.000000000', 'message': "Fix use of venv in Tempest.

Currently when running Tempest tests with run_tests.sh a venv
isn't being used. This leaves tempest at the mercy of whatever
required package versions are installed on the system.

This patch takes install_venv.py and with_venv.sh from nova and
integrates them into run_tests to ensure that the correct
dependencies versions from pip-requires and test-requires are
being used.

Change-Id: I4bf4a02890a33c4034e4493d1763ed4019fdf46e
"}]
commit_message:
Fix use of venv in Tempest.

Currently when running Tempest tests with run_tests.sh a venv
isn't being used. This leaves tempest at the mercy of whatever
required package versions are installed on the system.

This patch takes install_venv.py and with_venv.sh from nova and
integrates them into run_tests to ensure that the correct
dependencies versions from pip-requires and test-requires are
being used.

Change-Id: I4bf4a02890a33c4034e4493d1763ed4019fdf46e

commit_message:
Add openstack-utils dep to swift proxy install

fixes bug 1048926

This guide uses the openstack-config command to setup the keystone
tokens etc for swift proxy, which is in the openstack-utils on
yum-based systems.

Change-Id: I3c81c3572d28a6555a24638969d1a39578cd9f01

commit_message:
Fix disk-image-create's getopt error handling:

We originally checked the return code of getopt, but subsequently
a debugging echo has been inserted and now we are checking the
return code of "echo", which is very rarely going to be useful.

Change-Id: I054fecaf6576d5e9d42b07159bba7d50335bf6cc

commit_message:
fix test_nbd using stubs

test_nbd was assigning object methods to fakes during
tests, however the method name changed, and assigning
to a new method doesn't cause an error. Change this
to a stubs approach instead.

Change-Id: I7f9bb0237bcea2a15505fe1ed0b0be438cdaefc2

subject: add parent/sub-resource support into Quantum API framework
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 1653, 'name': 'garyk', 'email': 'gkotton@vmware.com', 'username': 'garyk'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}, {'_account_id': 4362, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 5948, 'name': 'Oleg Bondarev', 'email': 'obondarev@mirantis.com', 'username': 'obondarev'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Oleg,

overall, the code looks good. This code should allow to dispatch calls such as "getpool_healthmonitors" to the plugin.

What I still do not see is how the dependent resource itself will be wired in the API router. In apiv2/base/router.py supported first-level resources are declared in a dict:

        resources = {'network': 'networks',
                     'subnet': 'subnets',
                     'port': 'ports'}

and then registered as follows:

        def _map_resource(collection, resource, params):
            allow_bulk = cfg.CONF.allow_bulk
            controller = base.create_resource(collection, resource,
                                              plugin, params,
                                              allow_bulk=allow_bulk)
            mapper_kwargs = dict(controller=controller,
                                 requirements=REQUIREMENTS,
                                 **col_kwargs)
            return mapper.collection(collection, resource,
                                     **mapper_kwargs)

We should probably rework that map to specify nested resources, and change accordingly the code that maps the resource to the API route mapper.

Also, another thing that it is worth considering is that this way of managing "collection attributes" as sub resources will probably prevent us for doing a "bulk insert" of the same attribute. For instance if you want to add "1","2","3" you all have to do:
POST /parent/<p_id>/collection/
body: {"item": "1"}

POST /parent/<p_id>/collection
body: {"item": "2"}

POST /parent/<p_id>/collection
body: {"item": "3"}


whereas you could just do
PUT /parent/<p_id>
body: {"collection": ["1","2","3"]}

It would be a shame to lose the above capability (which is what we do at the moment with fixed_ips, that have some aspect in commons with the healthmonitors)'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sure.

to cut a long story short, while we want to modify a collection such a sub-resource we should allow bulk updated of the collection as whole.

And on this it seems that we're on the same page. I also see that the community has voted in favour of sub resources. (I kind of understood the approach of just using the attribute as a list was not favoured since it was ignored!)

My point is just that the 'sub-resource' at the end of the day is stil an attribute of the parent resource and the API should treat it as such.

Hence this is why I think that

POST /pools
{ ...pool stuff...
  "health_monitors": [ "id_1", "id_2", ... ]
  ... other pool stuff ...
}

is more appropriate than

POST /pools
{ ...pool stuff... }

and then 

POST /pools/pool_id/health_monitors
{
 ["id1", "id2", "id3"]
} 

this won't affect the ability of adding/removing single elements from a pool.
As it seems it's just you and me discussing this topic here, I'd move it back to the mailing list, with your permission.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

On 28 November 2012 11:28, obondarev (Code Review) <review@openstack.org> wrote:
>
> obondarev has posted comments on this change.
>
> Change subject: add parent/sub-resource support into Quantum API framework
> ......................................................................
>
>
> Patch Set 1:
>
> Hi Salvatore,
> many thanks for the review.
> Regarding the first thing you mentioned: actually I thought that ExtensionMiddleware will be used for mapping dependent resources to their parents as it has such ability and nothing should be changed there - so it suits well for the extension resources. 

I do apologise but I was not thinking of the middleware in the extension manager. The way the mapping is performed there is different, and the mapping should end invoking methods in the form <action><parent_resource>_<resource>. So for instance GET /pool/<pool-id>/healthmonitors will map to getpool_healthmonitors.

> As for APIRouter I remember you wrote that it is used for mapping core API resources and this is for historical reasons only. Do you think we should modify it too to support parents/sub-resources?

Yes for the first part (core resources only), not really for the second one (historical reasons). The 'historical reasons' are that the extension framework was never updated to use the code for the V2 API and so we now are in a situation where core and extensions have distinct ways of mapping routes. This is a long standing issue in the Quantum API that needs to be tackled, but it is outside of the scope of the discussion we're having here.

>
> Regarding the second issue I'll try to explain how I see we can support "bulk insert". Actually I planned to add additional resource to the RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP of LBaaS extension - called smth like health_monitor_references or *_ids. It may look like this:
>
> 'health_monitor_references': {
>         'health_monitors': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False,
>                             'default': [],
>                             'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None},
>                             'is_visible': True},
>     }

Seems this is a first-level resource which contains a collection of health monitors. If get_resources of LBAAS extension just iterates over elements in RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP you will end up health_monitor_references as a first level resource. Is that what you're aiming for?

>
> Then when creating controller and resource specify just "health_monitors" name and parent resource "pool" (to have pools/pool_id/health_monitors REST calls). I believe it should allow associating several health monitors for a pool with one POST call. What do you think?

If I get it right you will allow something like that:

POST /pools

{
 "name": "<name>"
 ... other stuff ...
 "health_monitors": [
   "<health-monitor-id1>",
   "<health-monitor-id2>",
   "<health-monitor-id3>",   
 ]
}

If that is your goal, I couldn't agree more. 
However, you were also referring to a POST /pools/pool_id/health_monitors for doing a bulk update of the sub-resource. I was initially thinking this would have been the way for adding an element to the collection of referenced health monitors.

While POST/PUT vs Create/Update are often debated in REST, the convention for Quantum (and Openstack as a whole) is that POST creates and PUT updates.
The operation you are referring to is probably more an "update" than a "create". I say this because I do not see health_monitors in pool as a real, independent, resource, but rather as a "collection attribute"; at least this is how I think the user should perceive it.

In theory I then think that the above POST should be allowed for creating a collection of references to health monitors, which could be updated in a 'bulk' way using the same syntax, but with a PUT method:

PUT /pools/<pool-id>

{
 "name": "<name>"
 ... other stuff ...
 "health_monitors": [
   "<health-monitor-id1>",
   "<new_health-monitor-id>",
   "<health-monitor-id3>",   
 ]
}

The sub-resource approach should expose collection-like operations (add, remove, set) using URI like:

POST /pools/<pool-id>/healthmonitors <- add to collection a reference
PUT /pools/<pool-id>/healthmonitors/<id> <- set an element of the collection (makes sense only if there are attributes other than the id of the referenced monitor)
DELETE /pools/<pool-id>/healthmonitors/<id> <- remove an element from the collection'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Oleg,
now that you've remove the draft state we should map this change to a bug or blueprint (probably more a bug).
As it is doing a non-trivial change in the API framework, we need to keep track of it! Therefore I'm setting a -1 to make sure it does not slip accidentally in.

You say a bulk operation will translate into a sequence of operations.
I was actually expecting the plugin to provide a way for allowing health monitor references for a pool to be updated as a list - thus giving the "bulk" behaviour "for free".

the underlying concept that I'm trying to implement is that of a collection, where you can either set the whole thing, or manipulate one at a time. It seems we're on the same page on this.

To this aim, I reckon the following operation:

GET /pools/<pool-id>

Should return health-monitors (or to be generic, the collection element), as from the point of view of the user it's just another attribute of the resource.
For this reason it is my opinion that the attribute, as a list, could be specified in operations like:

POST /pools/<pool-id>

without having to do:

POST /pools/<pool-id>/health-monitors

It seems this is going to be tricky for the route mapper, but I am confident a solution can be found.

This is actually the only thing I would like to change in your current proposal. This is for two reasons:
1) We have to be consistent throughout the API. In the port object, we have the fixed_ips attribute, which is a list too. Similarly we have dns_nameservers and host_routes in the subnet object. Those attributes are currently set as lists from the parent resource. Ideally one would like to expose them as collections too, but doing it as it is proposed now would break backward compatibility.

2) Users will need to do two calls for creating a pool resource, whereas the child resources could be instead embedded in the body of the parent resource.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

forgot to -1

Also, this patch will need unit tests for code coverage, and a dummy API extension to validate the behaviour.

I can do that and send you a diff, if that's ok for you."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Salvatore,

Yes, adding health monitor sub-resource to RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP is a mistake, I think we should create kind of SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP which in our case may look like:

SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = {
    'health_monitors': {
        'parent': {'collection_name': 'pools',
                           'member_name': 'pool'},
        'parameters': {'id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False,
                                               'validate': {'type:uuid': None},
                                               'is_visible': True}}
    }                         
}

Then in the extension (after adding all top level resources including health_monitors) add sub-resources, like this:

        for collection_name in SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP:
            resource_name = collection_name[:-1]
            parent = SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.get(collection_name, {}).get('parent')
            params = SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.get(collection_name, {}).get('parameters')

            controller = base.create_resource(collection_name,
                                              resource_name,
                                              plugin, params,
                                              parent['member_name'],
                                              allow_bulk=True,
                                              member_actions=member_actions)

            resource = extensions.ResourceExtension(collection_name,
                                                    controller, parent,
                                                    member_actions=
                                                    member_actions)
            resources.append(resource)


"allow_bulk=True" should provide an ability to emulate bulk create in base.Controller.

Overall this will lead to the following mappings:
GET /pools/{pool_id}/health_monitors -> plugin.get_pool_health_monitors(context, pool_id)
POST /pools/{pool_id}/health_monitors body: { health_monitors: [ {"id": id1}, {"id": id2} ]} -> series of calls inside Controller: plugin.create_pool_health_monitor(context, pool_id, health_monitor={"id": id1}), plugin.create_pool_health_monitor(context, pool_id, health_monitor={"id": id2}) - to associate several health monitors with a pool in one REST call and
POST /pools/{pool_id}/health_monitors body: {"id": id1} -> plugin.create_pool_health_monitor(context, pool_id, health_monitor={"id": id1}) - associates one healthmon at a time
DELETE /pools/{pool_id}/health_monitors/{id} -> plugin.delete_pool_health_monitor(context, pool_id, id)

Do you see any issues with such approach?'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Link to Youcef's summary:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-November/003361.html"}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yep, sure, let's go back to mail for a wider auditory."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Salvatore. 
Ok, Iâ€™ll create a bug for this patch. Also the diff with UT is definitely ok.

But Iâ€™m a little bit confused here as I thought we agreed on the approach 3 from Youcefâ€™s summary email (11/27/2012) â€“ so thatâ€™s why we need a sub-resource support in the API framework. 
It seems to me that you are now speaking mostly about approach 2 (as fixed_ips in port resource are done) â€“ Iâ€™m fine with it too but Iâ€™m not sure if we need sub-resources here at all. Can you please clarify you vision a bit more?'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Salvatore,
many thanks for the review.
Regarding the first thing you mentioned: actually I thought that ExtensionMiddleware will be used for mapping dependent resources to their parents as it has such ability and nothing should be changed there - so it suits well for the extension resources. As for APIRouter I remember you wrote that it is used for mapping core API resources and this is for historical reasons only. Do you think we should modify it too to support parents/sub-resources?

Regarding the second issue I'll try to explain how I see we can support "bulk insert". Actually I planned to add additional resource to the RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP of LBaaS extension - called smth like health_monitor_references or *_ids. It may look like this:

'health_monitor_references': {
        'health_monitors': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False,
                            'default': [],
                            'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None},
                            'is_visible': True}, 
    }

Then when creating controller and resource specify just "health_monitors" name and parent resource "pool" (to have pools/pool_id/health_monitors REST calls). I believe it should allow associating several health monitors for a pool with one POST call. What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/16888/2/check/gate-quantum-python27/2642 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(23 inline comments)

Thanks for working on this.  Most of my comments are around adding **kwargs to many of the methods.  Many of these methods can easily define an optional parent_id keyword arg and reduce the amount because you won't have to manage this variable. We should generally avoid accepting **kwargs unless there is a clear use case."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (23 inline comments)

Many thanks for your comments Mark. The only reason for using kwargs in most places is that in incoming requests as well as in plugin handlers parent_id will be named as <parent_name>_id. So my main concern is about unknown keyword parameter error.'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-18 14:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
add parent/sub-resource support into Quantum API framework

- quantum.api.v2.base.Controller class now able to handle sub-resources
- quantum.api.v2.router.APIRouter now able to specify sub-resources

Fixes bug 1085968

Change-Id: I07f2c1f3d974f7f17d4947804bde064dd8004a84

commit_message:
module refactoring

Distributes the functionality of service.py into the modules.
Moves ComposableRouters into the modules.
The routers and controllers now have short names.
The controllers get their APIs via the base class.

Change-Id:  I87404b80ea9800d6792f97a7a3a64fe839065c1c

[{'created': '2012-12-14 13:54:06.000000000', 'message': 'Test to GET public-readable container's object

Added a test case to "test_object_services.py" which tries to GET
public readable object with an empty header. Added a new class
"ObjectClientCustomizedHeader" to object_client.py inorder to overwrite
the http request with an empty header, which makes the test case to
"Make container public-readable, and access the object anonymously
without using credentials" with proper verification

commit_message:
Test to GET public-readable container's object

Added a test case to "test_object_services.py" which tries to GET
public readable object with an empty header. Added a new class
"ObjectClientCustomizedHeader" to object_client.py inorder to overwrite
the http request with an empty header, which makes the test case to
"Make container public-readable, and access the object anonymously
without using credentials" with proper verification

Change-Id: I407ceffefb6a99cbfa3bb31421189190aa3f8c1c
Implements: blueprint add-some-functional-swift-tests

commit_message:
Clear out the keystone pki data for each run

This prevents old invalid tokens from working after a rerun of stack.sh
and potentially providing users and tenants that don't exist.

Fixes bug 1089700

Change-Id: Icfc22978e41e459d51b50bc7ad2e6d98d766e402

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-13 11:09:50.000000000', 'message': 'Always chown $KEYSTONE_CONF_DIR

If the directory exists but is owned by another user, then this will
cause failures.

Note that we already do this for other components (glance, for
instance).

Change-Id: Ic7d2a2dd179f721636afc9ea9c3fe6bb314c9b33
'}]
commit_message:
Always chown $KEYSTONE_CONF_DIR

If the directory exists but is owned by another user, then this will
cause failures.

Note that we already do this for other components (glance, for
instance).

Change-Id: Ic7d2a2dd179f721636afc9ea9c3fe6bb314c9b33

commit_message:
Update aggregates test for aggregates bp

Instead of implementing availability zones in the service table,
availability zones will be implemented using general aggregate metadata.

So when an aggregate is created it will already have metadata.

Part of blueprint aggregate-based-availability-zones

Change-Id: I0fd22399b99a14087fef63fc91d0baef746efbed

messages: [{'account_id': 5930, 'date': '2012-12-18 07:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nwrong submission (I attempted to update an existing change...)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-18 07:14:18.000000000', 'message': 'Started to add zVM support

Started to implement virt driver for zVM hypervisor. Generally,
the driver will operate zVM hypervisor through xCat REST API. xCat
has a control point(a virtual machine) in zVM system, which enables
xCat management node to control the zVM system. OpenStack zVM
driver will communicate with xCat management node through xCat REST
API. Thus OpenStack can operate to zVM system indirectly.

Change-Id: I226fc4ff075081e4192ec9005fcb3e1e3c980825
Implements: blueprint zvm-virt-driver
'}]
commit_message:
Started to add zVM support

Started to implement virt driver for zVM hypervisor. Generally,
the driver will operate zVM hypervisor through xCat REST API. xCat
has a control point(a virtual machine) in zVM system, which enables
xCat management node to control the zVM system. OpenStack zVM
driver will communicate with xCat management node through xCat REST
API. Thus OpenStack can operate to zVM system indirectly.

Change-Id: I226fc4ff075081e4192ec9005fcb3e1e3c980825
Implements: blueprint zvm-virt-driver

'}, {'created': '2012-12-17 23:11:55.000000000', 'message': "Added override for swift-init's KILL_WAIT

You can now give swift-init a -k N (or --kill-wait N) option to
override the default 15 second wait for a process to die after

DocImpact

commit_message:
Added override for swift-init's KILL_WAIT

You can now give swift-init a -k N (or --kill-wait N) option to
override the default 15 second wait for a process to die after
sending it the die signal. This is useful for boxes that are awfully
slow for whatever reason.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I328ec254f6e0ee1cd423c1d062ba4c5331bd8337

commit_message:
Add a developer trap for api samples

This adds a test in test_api_samples to verify that no new extensions
get added to the tree without matching api_samples. Since not all the
extensions currently in the tree have samples, there is an exclusion
list so that this passes now. Extensions should never be added to that
exclusion list, and the list should eventually go away when we get
all of the extensions tested.

Change-Id: I506450d2f3f5a32ff5c653b5940bae6c47790d01

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-03 21:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17274/

In a merge proposal at [1] tried to add a YYYY-MM-DD entry point into the
api, and received flack for that in the reviews and on mailing list at
[2].  As a consumer, I find "experimental" to be difficult to interact
with, as It is not versioned at all.  Code that ran today with what will
eventually be version ed 2013-04-XX will break after that.  I'd much
rather have logic that handled the existence of a YYYY-MM-DD than figuring
out what exactly 'experimental' meant inside cloud-init.

I don't want the MD issue to derail this MP, but it did derail mine.

Now on to other actual review comments:
a) Is there some way or intent for the user to get the result of the post to
   password?  The gist at [3] seems to imply there is.  You clearly dont
   need this if you just want to write it to /dev/console for scraping.
b) this clearly only works with the Metadata service, and will not work
   with config drive.
c) If the user can get the content that the instance posts, then I am
   immediately wanting to the host's public keys there.  Ie, this would
   allow the user a secure (api over https) way to access the randomly
   generated public keys of their host, and not have to scrape *that*
   from user-data.
d) If there are multiple use cases for this immediately, then maybe
   openstack should just get out of the way, and expose a generic
   key/value store to be posted to inside the MD rather than just password
   and ssh public keys.  Then solutions can be built around convention
   that develops without change to openstack.

My biggest concern is that there is/was a strong desire from some parties
to have config drive and no metadata service, so if we build in nice
function into a MD that not everyone wants to have, we have to
re-implement that elsewhere or basically make the MD a requirement.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14550/ 
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-November/002479.html
[3] https://gist.github.com/4008762'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-03 21:38:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-03 21:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

"In a merge proposal at [1] tried to add a YYYY-MM-DD entry point into the.. 

Smoser: The intention is 'experimental' is just used during development and it is changed to a date at release time.

a)  yes, see the dependent branch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17273/
b) correct, this isn't inteded to work with config drive
c) & d) Others have requested generic data, but I'm concerned with is security. This write-once to a specific key so an untrusted user can't throw a bunch of random metadata into the cloud system. I think we need to be very careful about what data we want writable. If we want to allow a public key to be written as well I could see that as valuable, but allowing arbitrary writes seems too dangerous.

"My biggest concern is that there is/was a strong desire from some parties to have config drive and no metadata service.."

Yes. This is another reason I'm not so happy about allowing arbitrary writes. I talked with RAX (who doesn't use the metadata service), and we have a plan for supporting this password write if you are not using the metadata service. In the simple case the compute node could just encrypt the existing admin password and set the system_metadata value. A slightly better solution would be to have the guest agent generate the password and send it back via the xenstore.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-03 21:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-03 21:58:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-12-03 22:10:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

"Smoser: The intention is 'experimental' is just used during development and it is changed to a date at release time."

Right, but unless I know what that date will be, as I write cloud-init to test this (or support it in 'raring') then I have to use the string 'experimental' and then later change cloud-init to support the new string.  Ie, your hard coded string here affects consumers also.

Reguarding security of a blob, you already have those issues.  You're allowing PASSWORD to be an encrypted blob that will be stored in the DB and obtained by the client.  Yes, it will only be one time.  Does that matter?

Ie, you've already got all the problems of storing a blob of user-data, and now you're adding one storing instance-posted data.  Other than space restrictions, I can just override the "password" field to carry whatever i want.

This isn't terrible, but it seems hacky, and my interest in making it more general is to get openstack out of the middle, and let consumers and producers use a generic service.


Ie, I'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-03 22:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

[{'created': '2012-12-01 01:23:34.000000000', 'message': "Allows an instance to post encrypted password

Exposes a new url in openstack metadata with two methods:

GET 169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/password # get password
POST 169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/password # post password

The password can only be set once and will be stored in an
instance_system_metadata value with the key 'password'

Part of blueprint get-password

Change-Id: I4bbee8326a09fe38d6393e9e70f009daae0c6ece
"}, {'created': '2012-12-01 01:49:59.000000000', 'message': "Allows an instance to post encrypted password

commit_message:
Allows an instance to post encrypted password

Exposes a new url in openstack metadata with two methods:

GET 169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/password # get password
POST 169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/password # post password

The password can only be set once and will be stored in an
instance_system_metadata value with the key 'password'

Part of blueprint get-password

Change-Id: I4bbee8326a09fe38d6393e9e70f009daae0c6ece

commit_message:
Register the control_exchange RPC option

Fixes bug #1031725

Have the control_exchange option be registered by Oslo, but allow
projects to override the default of 'openstack' by doing e.g.:

  rpc.set_defaults(control_exchange='nova')

Change-Id: Ic6e534d9a70a1cfc94207b78caa57e897cf78f63

Oh do I have to review my own changeset in order for you to see my replies? I did comment on it, but seems like its still in draft state. That would explain why people don't reply to my comments! Another copy here just in case :-)

This change was required to be able to extend actions in network_associate.py. If disassociate is implemented through an action function in the resource extension it masks any action controller extensions in network_associate.py. By moving it into its own controller extension it co-operates with the network_associate controller extension and at the same time from the REST API point of view preserves the original behaviour"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-11-29 22:22:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Add more association support to network API

Adds API support to:
- Disassociate only host from network
- Disassociate only project from network
- Associate network with host (project already supported)

New functionality is added to a new extension networks_associate,
but the original networks extension is modified to allow networks_associate
to extend how it needs to. The original behavior of the networks extension is
preserved (no new functionality, nor change in existing behavior) in
terms of the API presented.

Bumps RPC API version for network RPC server version in order add
the associate function which allows to both associate and disassociate
a network with a host and or tenant. Has overlap with disassociate
and add_network_to_project but these are kept for backwards compatibility

DocImpact
Implmenents: blueprint apis-for-nova-manage
Change-Id: I78fd76e0696d1c872646355ab04d32f051551def

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-12 23:14:16.000000000', 'message': "Fix middleware logging for swift

Swift sets 'log_name' in the conf, and this can be used to set the
correct logger.  This patch moves the log configuration to
initialization so that the logger can be set appropriately and the
middleware will log to the swift proxy logs.  This also requires the
following review in swift to work:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17983/

Fixes bug #1089664

Change-Id: I315102ba277ac1f5ff92f4d79ae745bf53559328
"}]
commit_message:
Fix middleware logging for swift

Swift sets 'log_name' in the conf, and this can be used to set the
correct logger.  This patch moves the log configuration to
initialization so that the logger can be set appropriately and the
middleware will log to the swift proxy logs.  This also requires the
following review in swift to work:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17983/

Fixes bug #1089664

Change-Id: I315102ba277ac1f5ff92f4d79ae745bf53559328

commit_message:
Prevent an uncaught exception from being rasied.

An uncaught TypeError will be raised if auth_ref.management_url is None.

Change-Id: I054aac24299c051afbc4497d56c6e286f5fa8616
Fixes: bug #1089188

subject: Add registry_client_timeout parameter
messages:
[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-12-14 18:34:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm worried about changing the default behavior from "no timeout" to "10 minutes". But I think that concern is probably a bit silly.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2012-12-17 13:29:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Mark,

Yes, I wondered about leaving the default behaviour unchanged, but reckoned even 10 minutes was overkill -- typically a registry request should be a sub-second operation.

I'd be happy to change the default if others feel that is for the best."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-12-17 18:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As for me, I think I've completely come around to 10 minutes being a great default. For all normal purposes its about the same as "forever", except that when the registry becomes unresponsive, you do eventually get your thread back.

Reaffirming +2'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-12-17 21:27:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-12 14:05:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add registry_client_timeout parameter

Add a "registry_client_timeout" parameter which specifies the
time, in seconds, that an API server will wait for a registry
request to complete.

This prevents API clients hanging indefinitely in the event
that the registry becomes unresponsive.

Addresses LP bug 1089391.

Change-Id: Ib27b6eecdcb65cbe644c156a0ca5cd0d0b4638dd
'}]
commit_message:
Add registry_client_timeout parameter

Add a "registry_client_timeout" parameter which specifies the
time, in seconds, that an API server will wait for a registry
request to complete.

This prevents API clients hanging indefinitely in the event
that the registry becomes unresponsive.

Addresses LP bug 1089391.

Change-Id: Ib27b6eecdcb65cbe644c156a0ca5cd0d0b4638dd

commit_message:
Port some additional logging changes from novaclient

* Allows capture of timestamps prior to and after request for timing
  https://review.openstack.org/11519
* Add -X to DELETE and PUT in debug mode
  https://review.openstack.org/12069
* Show request body in curl command
  https://review.openstack.org/12203

Change-Id: I0d87ab6b3c2b35ff843323cb818915e03993a844

While this approach works, the problem is it will mask misconfigurations and other possible errors.

I'd like to do two things:

    1. Keep this code as-is but log an error if the exception case is hit.

    2. Find the places in the codebase where this was *not* being properly checked and wrap them in an is_service_enabled call so that we can intercept these problems at a higher level and deal with them more appropriate in the UI."}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2012-12-10 12:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2012-12-10 12:56:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree, there should be tests to check, if volume service is not enabled, the pages don't crash any more. Sadly, I was still unable to fake a cinder client based on a different keystone configuration. commit_message:
Avoid cinder calls, when cinder is unavailable

When a volume service is not available, then a cinder client can not
be created. This patch skips the calls, so that dashboard doesn't
break any more.

Change-Id: Ic5d029302d10b453257b452ba78541febf8e4c96
Fixes bug 1084137

commit_message:
Adds a "simplified" floating IP management option.

Provides one-click associate and disassociated actions when in
"simple" floating IP management mode. Complex floating IP
management is still allowed via the access & security panel,
but in general it's not necessary except when managing multiple
floating IP pools or with complex network requirements.

Implements blueprint associate-ip-one-click.

Change-Id: Iaa9333b4f9a0c1590fcee50d1e56fcbaa21a84dc

[{'created': '2012-12-17 19:01:31.000000000', 'message': "GettingStarted: Install python-pip package

pip-python is not installed by default, so we need to install it in order
to be able to use it. (An alternative would be to use easy_install, which
is packaged as part of setuputils and therefore already present, but it
lacks any of pip-python's package management capabilities.)

Change-Id: I6a620d0864b6671348bbcf962c3c2cde06f9ed83
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
GettingStarted: Install python-pip package

pip-python is not installed by default, so we need to install it in order
to be able to use it. (An alternative would be to use easy_install, which
is packaged as part of setuputils and therefore already present, but it
lacks any of pip-python's package management capabilities.)

Change-Id: I6a620d0864b6671348bbcf962c3c2cde06f9ed83
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add tox artifacts to .gitignore

 * A tox build creates quantum/versioninfo and setuptools-*.egg,
   and git formerly marked them as untracked rather than ignored.

Change-Id: I50556717a05b2488cff5d9693d46637df608da70

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-17 16:51:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fix issues with deleting a WaitCondition

Previously we were ignoring the reference to the WaitConditionHandle stored
in the database by always setting it to None on load. This meant that we
had to try to recreate it on delete, which would fail if e.g. the
WaitConditionHandle had already been deleted.

bug 1089354

Change-Id: Ibc4145348a91b455e97ba27748ff72451b0c7bce
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2012-12-17 19:01:32.000000000', 'message': 'Fix issues with deleting a WaitCondition

Previously we were ignoring the reference to the WaitConditionHandle stored
in the database by always setting it to None on load. This meant that we
had to try to recreate it on delete, which would fail if e.g. the
WaitConditionHandle had already been deleted.

bug 1089354

Change-Id: Ibc4145348a91b455e97ba27748ff72451b0c7bce
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix issues with deleting a WaitCondition

Previously we were ignoring the reference to the WaitConditionHandle stored
in the database by always setting it to None on load. This meant that we
had to try to recreate it on delete, which would fail if e.g. the
WaitConditionHandle had already been deleted.

bug 1089354

Change-Id: Ibc4145348a91b455e97ba27748ff72451b0c7bce
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix importing of novaclient exceptions

Broken by 3c702e38e9a51a15a8d1626b60f610c75cb1f8b7

Also, use novaclient's own mechanism for selecting the correct API version;
don't go fishing in the internals.

Change-Id: I296312f185735026587ba9849343aa79177856a3
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-12-17 16:50:48.000000000', 'message': 'Pin docutils to 0.9.1.

Docutils 0.10 breaks manpage generation in sphinx 1.1.3. A fix to
sphinx has been merged, but not yet released (scheduled for dec
24-31). In the mean time, we should pin docutils to 0.9.1.

Fixes bug 1091333.

Change-Id: I157f3c191bfc09d2191a3508d81bcbaea56205a6
'}]
commit_message:
Pin docutils to 0.9.1.

Docutils 0.10 breaks manpage generation in sphinx 1.1.3. A fix to
sphinx has been merged, but not yet released (scheduled for dec
24-31). In the mean time, we should pin docutils to 0.9.1.

Fixes bug 1091333.

Change-Id: I157f3c191bfc09d2191a3508d81bcbaea56205a6

commit_message:
Add accounting for orphans to resource tracker.

Add accounting for orphaned instances to resource tracker.  Orphans
are instances that, for whatever reason, exist on the hypervisor
but are not accounted for in the Nova DB.

Such instances would cause resource tracker to under-report usage
numbers and result in out of memory errors during build.

Change-Id: Icc970e34e01ff8c7dfb000889e5ea6e2d0421c77

use_syslog to True. You can specify a facility (syslog_log_facility)

commit_message:
Add syslogging to nova-rootwrap

Add syslogging capabilities to nova-rootwrap, if you set parameter
use_syslog to True. You can specify a facility (syslog_log_facility)
and level (syslog_log_level) to use. Finalizes bp nova-rootwrap-options.

In doing so, it moves rootwrap config parsing to a nova.rootwrap.wrapper
object (and adds unit testing for it). It also improves log messages
content (including the name of the matching filter and the escalation
path used). Incidentally fixes bug 1084766.

Change-Id: Idb8cd9c9febd6263dafab4bc2bff817f00c53dc0

commit_message:
Replace fixtures.DetailStream with fixtures.StringStream.

Fixtures 0.3.12 adds StringStream as a successor to DetailStream (this
change was made for compatibility with python 3). Update Nova's tests to
use StringStream instead of DetailStream.

Change-Id: If697859a52f3a7db9dab38bd080b779bb3270287

commit_message:
Separate instructions for installing mysql/rabbit

fixes bug Bug984977

This ensures mysql is installed before it is needed, and avoids
 confusion

patch 2 adds the missing files from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17951

and updates the commit mesage to be more readable

Change-Id: I55cebb45d9c4e4d80688dce2848c7736e78eb3d3

I'm not really convinced that this is suitable for the stable tree as is. This change to Nova will not work without the corresponding change to Quantum being deployed. While find for a new major version release, IMHO, this kind of requirement to lock-step upgrade both Nova & Quantum at the same time is not something that would be expected for a stable update.

I would -1 this change myself, but will leave that decision up to the stable tree maintainers."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-28 10:15:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Gary"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

i agree with yong's point."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I've marked the associated bug as invalid. To make multiple ranges of VLANs on the same physical network available for tenant network allocation, simply list multiple ranges for the same physical network in network_vlan_ranges on the server. Instead of:

network_vlan_ranges = physnet1:1000:2000,physnet2:2001:3000

you should specify:

network_vlan_ranges = physnet1:1000:2000,physnet1:2001:3000

-Bob"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Only one physical network should map to a network interface (or bridge). If you need multiple VLAN ranges on the same network interface, then the network_vlan_ranges variable in the server should list multiple ranges for the same physical network name.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If does ovs agent need the same change?'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It seems just to modify that parameter is not enough. But I think It is reasonably to have this feature."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think It is reasonable for many vlan IDs mapped to one physical net card.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If does ovs agent need the same change?"}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Then I tested it with linuxbridge plugin again, it works.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi, Christian, Sorry for my comment, I test with wrong plugin. Please ignore my comment. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi, Christian, I do some test as below:

network_vlan_ranges = physnet1:1000:2000,physnet2:2001:3000
bridge_mappings = physnet1:br-eth0,physnet2:br-eth0

Then create two network:

quantum net-create net1 --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network physnet1 --provider:segmentation_id 2000
quantum subnet-create net1 10.0.0.0/24

quantum net-create net2 --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network physnet2 --provider:segmentation_id 3001
quantum subnet-create net2 11.0.0.0/24

Then dump the flow table,
sudo ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-eth0
NXST_FLOW reply (xid=0x4):
 cookie=0x0, duration=259.345s, table=0, n_packets=33, n_bytes=6373, priority=2,in_port=9 actions=drop
 cookie=0x0, duration=160.858s, table=0, n_packets=4, n_bytes=308, priority=4,in_port=9,dl_vlan=1 actions=mod_vlan_vid:2000,NORMAL
 cookie=0x0, duration=22.775s, table=0, n_packets=0, n_bytes=0, priority=4,in_port=8,dl_vlan=2 actions=mod_vlan_vid:3001,NORMAL
 cookie=0x0, duration=259.644s, table=0, n_packets=0, n_bytes=0, priority=1 actions=NORMAL

sudo ovs-ofctl show br-eth0
OFPT_FEATURES_REPLY (xid=0x1): ver:0x1, dpid:0000f0def15a0b0a
n_tables:255, n_buffers:256
features: capabilities:0xc7, actions:0xfff
 1(eth0): addr:f0:de:f1:5a:0b:0a
     config:     0
     state:      LINK_DOWN
     current:    COPPER AUTO_NEG
     advertised: 10MB-HD 10MB-FD 100MB-HD 100MB-FD 1GB-FD COPPER AUTO_NEG
     supported:  10MB-HD 10MB-FD 100MB-HD 100MB-FD 1GB-FD COPPER AUTO_NEG
 9(phy-br-eth0): addr:92:6a:40:80:76:b8
     config:     0
     state:      0
     current:    10GB-FD COPPER
 LOCAL(br-eth0): addr:f0:de:f1:5a:0b:0a
     config:     PORT_DOWN
     state:      LINK_DOWN



So found this entry for net2:
 cookie=0x0, duration=22.775s, table=0, n_packets=0, n_bytes=0, priority=4,in_port=8,dl_vlan=2 actions=mod_vlan_vid:3001,NORMAL

But didn't find in_port=8 in br-eth0.

So it looks like it doesn't work with same physical interface for several network_vlan_ranges.

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-12-17 11:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Robert Kukura (rkukura):

If you want multiple ranges of VLANs available for tenant network allocation on the same physical network, simply list multiple ranges for the same physical network in network_vlan_ranges on the server. For example:

network_vlan_ranges = physnet1:1000:2000,physnet1:2001:3000'}]

commit_message:
mapping of several vlan ranges to one physical network

In Quantum 2012.2 it was possible to use the same physical interface for
several network_vlan_ranges.

With Quantum 2012.2.1 and Grizzly this feature got removed, because now
the method utils.parse_mappings is be used for parsing the
physical_interface_mappings variable without using the parameter
unique_values=False.

fixes bug 1090436

commit_message:
Instantiate inspector in compute manager

As suggested in the review of the original inspector patch
(I20700320dd7e3196507173c780ab598b479e4021), the inspector
lifecycle is now controlled by the compute manager as
opposed to the pollsters.

Change-Id: Ifdef5ab22e7fb224e273dae5dbff3fb4dab10031

commit_message:
dhcp_agent.ini, l3_agent.ini: update dhcp/l3_agent.ini

Bug 1089223
RyuInterfaceDriver is eliminated, so update the example of
dhcp_agent.ini, l3_agent.ini for Ryu plugin and other OVS
based plugins.

Change-Id: Icc95c213ecd96946bd5a90d5d60df88c94cc1454

commit_message:
Standardise client imports

Do all client imports once, in the clients module, using the normal
OpenStack idiom for optional imports where appropriate.

Change-Id: I1186eba21159fe20e80c1947779fd164dada5880
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update test_router_list to validate the router returned.

For unit test test_l3_plugin.L3NatExtensionTestCase.test_router_list,
correctly validate the value returned from listing the routers.

Fixes bug 1078150

Change-Id: I5ae559c37f43c1b977065a3508b6efb4375a2c1a

commit_message:
Fixed the security group port binding should be automatically
deleted when delete_port

Added the CASCADE setting for the security group port
binding database model.

Also removed unused variables and imports

Fixes: bug #1080887

Change-Id: Id1af121b6ee57b794cb515a0b0c26b9a6310fbc4

commit_message:
CHAP support for IBM Storwize/SVC driver.

This implements support for CHAP authentication of hosts by the IBM
Storwize/SVC controller. A host entity was created on the controller for
each server that logs in with iSCSI. Now a randomly-generated CHAP
secret is added to the host entity on the controller (passed via the
controller CLI over SSH).

Implements blueprint add-chap-support-to-storwize-svc-driver

Change-Id: I60b5ddd0ea2e1ede3070779e5293820480aa0401

commit_message:
make the DHCP agent use a unique queue name

fixes bug: 1084621

This generates a unique name, so that multiple agents can be active
within a deployment.

Change-Id: Ia2bdc27866e6aa4aebd0bd28d1dfd25c3167dd03

I'll update the patch."}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2012-12-17 03:15:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmm I Looked at devstack more closely. Other components check only "$KEYSTONE_TOKEN_FORMAT" == "PKI".
In the case of KEYSTONE_TOKEN_FORMAT = UUID, they depends on fact that signing_dir is not defined.
 
Which do you prefer to fix devstack/lib/quantum or etc/quantum/api-paste.ini?'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-12-17 03:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

For more discussion please see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17843/ and Dean's comment in https://bugs.launchpad.net/devstack/+bug/1088801."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-12-17 03:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-17 03:15:28.000000000', 'message': "etc/api-paste.ini: make devstack work

Bug 1089224
As other openstack project, comment out signing_dir. Otherwise quantum-server
fails to start with devstack as follows with keystone

> 2012-12-12 14:26:53 13899 CRITICAL quantum [-] [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/var/lib/quantum/keystone-signing'

Change-Id: I3619aa91c35f887ca2ca3a32d9355f335905d4df
"}]
commit_message:
etc/api-paste.ini: make devstack work

Bug 1089224
As other openstack project, comment out signing_dir. Otherwise quantum-server
fails to start with devstack as follows with keystone

> 2012-12-12 14:26:53 13899 CRITICAL quantum [-] [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/var/lib/quantum/keystone-signing'

Change-Id: I3619aa91c35f887ca2ca3a32d9355f335905d4df

commit_message:
Support dash-style options for security-group commands.

Fixes bug 1090233
underscore-stype options are still supported for backward compatibility.

Also add secgroup name support for --source-group-id.

Change-Id: I5947ae510e074db612dae1431487fe9ca195a467

[{'created': '2012-12-12 22:59:38.000000000', 'message': "Fix needed for keystone middleware logging

This is required for a fix in keystone middleware to log to the proxy
logs.  Since the keystone middleware doesn't initialize the log with
swift.commong.utils.config_logger, it doesn't have the server and
transaction id setup.  This is required to fix bug #1089664

Change-Id: Icbb44076495a4d56065445c7a4d972ebede5d1e0
"}, {'created': '2012-12-12 23:31:12.000000000', 'message': "Fix needed for keystone middleware logging

This is required for a fix in keystone middleware to log to the proxy
logs.  Since the keystone middleware doesn't initialize the log with
swift.commong.utils.config_logger, it doesn't have the server and
transaction id setup.  This is required to fix bug #1089664

Change-Id: Icbb44076495a4d56065445c7a4d972ebede5d1e0
"}]
commit_message:
Fix needed for keystone middleware logging

This is required for a fix in keystone middleware to log to the proxy
logs.  Since the keystone middleware doesn't initialize the log with
swift.commong.utils.config_logger, it doesn't have the server and
transaction id setup.  This is required to fix bug #1089664

Change-Id: Icbb44076495a4d56065445c7a4d972ebede5d1e0

commit_message:
Move provider_fw_rule_get_all to conductor

This patch moves the compute/manager's use of the
provider_fw_rule_get_all() method to the conductor.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute-manager

Change-Id: I963fc65046d29b6eb92b82d559593a64ff775632

commit_message:
Move security_group operations in VirtAPI to conductor

This patch adds the following methods to conductor's API and
redirects the use of them in nova-compute to conductor:

  security_group_get_by_instance()
  security_group_rule_get_by_security_group()

This involved changing the corresponding VirtAPI methods to
accept actual objects instead of IDs, to avoid introducing
additional DB messaging behavior.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute-manager

Change-Id: I14c2bcd181d0e0a1ec17130917c1a7eb0a091cf2

[{'created': '2012-12-14 14:30:05.000000000', 'message': "Remove instance quota re-sync code

Obviously came in inadvertantly in a copy'n'paste from the
nova quotas logic.

Not relevant to volume quotas and would fail if ever called
(as instance_data_get_for_project is not part of the cinder
DB API).

Change-Id: Ib52b962b51003955430ad292084a3e3010736a2c
"}]
commit_message:
Remove instance quota re-sync code

Obviously came in inadvertantly in a copy'n'paste from the
nova quotas logic.

Not relevant to volume quotas and would fail if ever called
(as instance_data_get_for_project is not part of the cinder
DB API).

Change-Id: Ib52b962b51003955430ad292084a3e3010736a2c

[{'created': '2012-12-14 21:48:44.000000000', 'message': 'Handle empty UserData for instance

UserData is not required, so handle the case where it is not supplied (i.e.
is None).

bug 1090544

Change-Id: If8bfe9ba2aafe3bb2e9de14b01c57d1ddcf9b21d
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Handle empty UserData for instance

UserData is not required, so handle the case where it is not supplied (i.e.
is None).

bug 1090544

Change-Id: If8bfe9ba2aafe3bb2e9de14b01c57d1ddcf9b21d
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make resource registration conditional

If client libraries are not present for Swift or Quantum, don't register
the corresponding resource types.

Change-Id: I95a42973775b7f4c1d82caa47dc0660dfe54bb21
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

Retry NBD device allocation.

Mitigates bug 726244.

"}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2012-12-13 00:44:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I've run into a couple of issues when trying this out:

MySQL-Python is being installed with version 1.2.4c1 by default which requires distribute 0.6.28 but only 0.6.24 appears to be available in pip. Forcing 1.2.4b5 doesn't work either but 1.2.3 does.

The tests appear to be run fine but I do get this warning in the output:

py27 runtests: commands[1]
WARNING:test command found but not installed in testenv
  cmd: /bin/bash
  env: /srv/compile/openstack/nova.testr/.tox/py27
Maybe forgot to specify a dependency?
  /srv/compile/openstack/nova.testr$ /bin/bash -c if [ ! -d ./.testrepository ] ; then testr init ; fi"}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2012-12-13 01:57:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2012-12-13 02:03:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

The mysql python thing is an issue not related to this patch as we don't have an upper bound on the mysql python package (you can get around this by pip installing latest tox or virtualenv).

The dependency warning thing has to do with using bash to clump a few operations together under tox and bash isn't being installed to the venv which results in the warning. Should be able to ignore it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-13 02:21:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22: Doesn't seem to work

some other way.

run_tests.sh has been updated to run testr instead of nosetests.

Coverage is collected by running subunit.run under coverage.py when the
coverage environment is selected.

Note that you will need to rebuild your virtualenvs as nose is being
removed from the dependency lists and is being replaced by testr. Tests
will run in different processes once this test is merged so you cannot
use test classes to pass information between tests. Each test should be
a proper independent unit. Additionally the -x and -d flags to
run_tests.sh have been removed as there are currently no decent

commit_message:
Use testr to run nova unittests.

Convert nova from using nosetests to testr for its test runner. Some
tests had to be modified to get them to run properly under testr.

run_tests.sh has been updated to run testr instead of nosetests.

Coverage is collected by running subunit.run under coverage.py when the
coverage environment is selected.

Note that you will need to rebuild your virtualenvs as nose is being
removed from the dependency lists and is being replaced by testr. Tests
will run in different processes once this test is merged so you cannot
use test classes to pass information between tests. Each test should be
a proper independent unit. Additionally the -x and -d flags to
run_tests.sh have been removed as there are currently no decent
approximations for those functions.

Change-Id: I019ca098972ca749b195f59968cf21edd5ba9109

Very nice.
Just a few minor inline issues and a question.
When I ran the tools I see that there are some False positives. 
For example:

./quantum/debug/debug_agent.py:153                 return "sudo ip netns exec %s" % self._get_namespace(port): Warn: Message might need localized

Is the localization also relevant to the help messages for the common configuration cfg data?

Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2012-12-15 00:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Add case 'LOG.xxx("Hello %s" % xyz) should be LOG.xxx("Hello %s", xyz)''}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2012-12-15 00:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2012-12-15 00:24:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: (3 inline comments)

Yes, there is some false positives. It because hard analyze the real meaning in the message. So I just put the message that we pretty ensure for need i18n as 'Error' message. Others just show as 'Warn' message. Let reviewer and developer decide.

I didn't find the help messages for the common configuration cfg data will show for user. But I think we can make those message as i18n message. Maybe in future, we will show it for user.

Thanks for your review!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-15 00:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Works for me

commit_message:
Add script for checking i18n message

Part of bp make-string-localizable

usage: tox -e i18n

tools/check_i18n.py: used check i18n message for one file.

tools/check_i18n_test_case.txt: test case of check_i18n.py.
run test case with cmd:
$ ./tools/check_i18n.py ./tools/check_i18n_test_case.txt -d

Change-Id: I2c383b7bb11ab3bdb8e3bb3b887342b1225840ac

commit_message:
Configure endpoint_type and service_type for swift

The swift store offers limited customization for picking out which swift
endpoint to use for image storage. This patch adds service_type and
endpoint_type customization, and extends these options to the
multi-tenant configuration. Also, the multi-tenant configuration now
honors the region configuration.

Fixes #1037708

Change-Id: I38054a2a681dbf05373870f6addcb9ddae7ed12e

[{'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-09-06 03:37:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

This basic smoke test has a stumbling block - the challenges faced in checking network connectivity:

 - If private network connectivity is to be tested, tempest must be local to an ovs bridge with local or remote connectivity to the vm's private network.  If namespaces are enabled, the debug agent would need to be used, but that would require both that quantum be installed and configured local to tempest and that tempest be permitted to run 'ip netns exec' as a privileged user.

 - If public network connectivity is to be tested, the quantum l3 agent needs to be configured and running (on each hypervisor?).  Support is coming in devstack to configure the l3 agent (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/11380/), but according to Salvatore the configuration is missing a final step at present for safety reasons - configuring the bridge with the external interface's ip and plugging that interface into the bridge.

This is only a first attempt - any and all feedback on how to provide for maintainability and extensibility is very much welcome."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-09-06 03:40:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

redo to fix the gerrit formatting.

This is definitely a work in progress - any and all feedback on how to provide for maintainability and extensibility is very much welcome.

This basic smoke test has a stumbling block - the challenges faced in checking network connectivity:

- If private network connectivity is to be tested, tempest must be local to an ovs bridge with local or remote connectivity to the vm's private network.  If namespaces are enabled, the debug agent would need to be used, but that would require both that quantum be installed and configured local to tempest and that tempest be permitted to run 'ip netns exec' as a privileged user.

- If public network connectivity is to be tested, the quantum l3 agent needs to be configured and running (on each hypervisor?).  Support is coming in devstack to configure the l3 agent (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/11380/), but according to Salvatore the configuration is missing a final step at present for safety reasons - configuring the bridge with the external interface's ip and plugging that interface into the bridge."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-09-06 03:59:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work
